                       CREDIT AND PROGRAM SUMMARY

                                     MONGOLIA

                       DEVELOPMENT POLICY CREDIT


Borrower                Mongolia
Implementing Agency     Ministry of Finance
Financing Data          IDA Credit Amount: US$40 million equivalent
                        Terms: The proposed operation is processed under IDA Financial
                        Crisis Response Fast-Track Facility
Operation Type          Single tranche operation to be disbursed upon loan effectiveness
                        This is the first of two single tranche Development Policy Credits
                        supporting government reforms to manage the economic downturn
Main Policy Areas       This Development Policy Credit (DPC) is designed to assist the
                        government manage the current downturn, which was triggered by
                        the collapse of the copper price. The DPC supports reforms in the
                        policy areas most affected: (i) fiscal policy and management, given
                        the budget's strong dependence on mining revenues; (ii) social
                        protection, given the impact of the economic downturn on the poor;
                        (iii) the financial sector, which was overheating when the global
                        crisis hit, and which experienced a major bank failure in late 2008;
                        and (iv) the mining sector, given the sector's importance in driving
                        the recovery.
Key Outcome Indicators  Improve capital budget planning and execution, and protect the
                        maintenance of basic infrastructure:
                             ·   Number of projects without feasibility studies reduced by
                                 30 projects (valued at MNT 19.8 billion)
                             ·   2009 budget outturn has maintained allocation for repairs
                                 and maintenance of basic infrastructure at MNT 12.4
                                 billion.


                        Protect the poor during the downturn by retargeting social policies
                        to the poor:
                             ·   At least 75 percent of the surveys to collect household level
                                 data for the national beneficiary database based on a proxy-
                                 means-test formula have been completed.


                        Strengthen confidence in the financial sector:
                             ·   Restructuring/resolution action plan for bank placed under
                                 conservatorship is implemented.
                             ·   A contingency planning framework for failed-bank
                                 resolution is in place.
                             ·   Crisis management and systemic risk monitoring task force
                                 with requisite legal and regulatory powers provides BoM,
                                 FSC and other relevant agencies with regular reports and
                                 leads quick and decisive action in case of possible bank
                                 failures.




                                             v

                          Clarify the mining policy framework:
                              ·   New investment agreements utilize draft model investment
                                  agreement,     including   responsible    mining     practices
                                  consistent with the Equator principles.
                              ·   New Cadastre Regulations adopted and implemented
                              ·   Responsible mining practices followed and monitored
                                  through enhanced regulatory capacity
                              ·   Independent validation of Mongolia's national EITI
                                  program undertaken.
Program Development       This Development Policy Credit (DPC) is designed to support
Objectives and            government efforts to: (i) improve capital budget planning and
Contribution to the ISN   execution, and protect the maintenance of basic infrastructure; (ii)
                          protect the poor during the downturn by retargeting existing social
                          policies to the poor; (iii) strengthen confidence in the financial
                          sector by preparing an action plan for the resolution of the failed
                          bank, and enhancing contingency planning and systemic risk
                          monitoring; and (iv) clarify the mining policy framework by
                          adopting draft model investment agreements, which incorporate
                          responsible   mining    practices, consistent    with   the  Equator
                          Principles; and finance the independent validation of Mongolia's
                          national EITI program. The centerpieces of the Interim Strategy
                          Note (ISN) are two single-tranche DPCs (FY10 and FY11). The
                          World Bank Group assistance under the ISN and the DPCs are fully
                          synchronized.
Risks and risk mitigation Significant risks include:
                              ·   Another fall in mineral prices, leading to further budget and
                                  external balance shocks. This risk is mitigated by the
                                  introduction of a more flexible exchange rate, more prudent
                                  fiscal management and removing uncertainties in the
                                  mining investment regime to promote foreign direct
                                  investment.
                              ·   More bank failures, mitigated by improved monetary and
                                  exchange     rate  policies,  enhanced      monitoring    and
                                  supervision of the banking sector and the establishment of a
                                  crisis management task force in the Bank of Mongolia.
                          Moderate risks include:
                              ·   Populist political pressures and/or a substantial rebound of
                                  the copper price could derail or reverse the fiscal, monetary
                                  and exchange-rate policy reforms needed to manage the
                                  downturn, mitigated by intensified outreach (through
                                  dialogue, workshops/conferences and regular economic
                                  updates) to policymakers, Parliament, academia, and the
                                  media with the objective to help build strong commitment
                                  to reforms.
                              ·   Government agrees to sub-optimal mineral export contracts
                                  or other non-concessional financing that negatively impacts
                                  debt sustainability. This is mitigated by development
                                  partners'   joint  support   for   the   appropriate   policy
                                  adjustments, backed by the necessary financial support,
                                  including this DPC.

Operation ID number       P115737


                                             vi

                                IDA PROGRAM DOCUMENT FOR A

                         PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT POLICY CREDIT

                                            TO MONGOLIA



                                       I.       INTRODUCTION


1.       The global downturn has hit Mongolia hard. This downturn has been most immediately
felt through the collapse of mineral prices, in particular that of copper. Given Mongolia's reliance
on copper revenues in the budget (more than one-third of the budget relies on mineral revenues),
the fiscal shock has been very large (from a 2.9 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
surplus in 2007 to a 5.0 percent of GDP deficit in 2008). Export proceeds are expected to fall by
one third (about US$800 million) this year. Inflation, fueled by domestic consumption (driven by
large increases in wages and salaries and untargeted social transfers) and loose monetary policies,
peaked at 34 percent in August 2008--the highest in the region. Economic growth is projected to
slow down sharply--it would fall from 8.9 percent in 2008 to a projected 2.7 percent in 2009.

2.       The proposed operation is processed under the International Development Association
(IDA) Financial Crisis Response Fast-Track Facility to help the government meet urgent
financing needs. The sudden downturn exposed the overreliance of the budget on mineral
revenues, causing the fiscal situation to become precarious. The downturn also exposed
weaknesses in an overheated banking sector, leading to a large systemically important bank being
placed under conservatorship and a loss of confidence, as demonstrated by declining deposits.
And foreign direct investment (FDI) in the mining sector, which was growing rapidly from a
small base, stagnated.

3.       Managing the downturn is now the over-riding government priority. The size of the
adjustments needed is such that multilateral and bilateral balance of payments support and budget
support is urgently needed. In response, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) agreed on April 1
to an 18-month Stand-By Arrangement (SBA) of US$229 million 1 to provide balance of
payments support. The SBA gives Mongolia exceptional access to IMF resources based on the
extraordinary nature of the external shock and the strong policy actions taken by the government.
Based on this agreement and the commitment of the government to undertake the necessary
reforms to adjust to the crisis, key development partners (the Asian Development Bank (ADB),
Japan and the World Bank) have indicated their willingness to provide the budget support needed
to co-finance the fiscal deficits under the IMF program. These deficits would have been difficult
to finance otherwise, given the lack of liquidity in the domestic banking sector and the
unattractiveness and unavailability of commercial external financing.

4.       The World Bank's proposed Development Policy Credit is a single-tranche operation of
US$40 million.2 The proposed instrument is a single-tranche operation, because of the existing


1The amount requested is fixed at SDR 153.3 million, which is equivalent to US$229 million on April 9,
2009.
2Mongolia's indicative IDA envelope for FY09-11 is assumed to be about SDR 60 million ($90 million at
current exchange rate), with actual allocations determined on an annual basis according to specific criteria.
Estimates of the IDA envelope for FY09-11 are indicative only and can change. Actual allocations in these
years will depend on: (i) total IDA resources available; (ii) the country's performance rating; (iii) the
performance and assistance terms of other IDA borrowers; (iv) the terms of IDA's assistance to Mongolia
(grants or credits); and (v) the number of IDA-eligible countries. IDA allocations are made in SDRs based
on performance, and the US$ equivalent is dependent upon the prevailing exchange rate. Since Mongolia is


                                                     1

uncertainties and risks, and the absence of a coherent and detailed medium-term policy
framework.3 However, because of the magnitude of the shock, it is clear that the adjustment effort
will take place over the next several years, and the government has started to outline a medium-
term agenda. Hence, a successor DPC of US$20 million is envisaged in FY2011.

5.       The policy actions to be supported by this operation are sharply targeted to the key crisis
areas--fiscal policy and management, social protection, and the financial sector--and the sector
that can lead the recovery--the mining sector. The cross-cutting theme is a familiar one: crisis
brings opportunity. The government is fully aware that the crisis has exposed a number of
mistakes and weaknesses in the policy regime, which it now wants to address with a sense of
urgency. There is a bi-partisan consensus around this recognition, which is demonstrated by the
strong policy actions taken in the last months. And the government also recognizes that the crisis
presents the opportunity to use these corrective actions to put an improved policy framework in
place going forward. For instance, the necessity of agreeing to a set of binding rules to the budget
approval process, which will help Mongolia manage the boom-and-bust cycle of its mining
revenues, is felt more clearly now, during the bust, than previously, during the boom. Re-
targeting the now universal social transfers not only helps restore sustainability to the budget, but
also holds the promise of creating a far more effective social protection program. Similarly,
addressing the current problems of the financial sector in a decisive and transparent manner can
pave the way for a much stronger financial sector in the years to come. Finally, removing the
instability and uncertainty, which had crept into the mining policy framework during the boom
years, sets the stage for a resumption of private sector investment needed to lead the economy out
of the bust.

6.       The support of Mongolia's multilateral and bilateral development partners comes at a
critical time and can have a high impact. This joint support will assist Mongolia to manage the
current downturn and set the stage for economic recovery, allowing the country to continue on the
path taken since 1990. The risks emanating from the external environment are significant, while
domestically, populism could undermine the adjustment efforts and cause social instability.
However, the actions so far taken by the current coalition government and approved by both
parties in Parliament have demonstrated a clear bi-partisan resolve to correct past mistakes and
set the stage for improved economic and fiscal policies. This DPC helps to support this resolve.



                                    II.       COUNTRY CONTEXT


7.       Mongolia has made tremendous political and economic progress since the transition that
started in the 1990s. Five parliamentary elections were held in the period since, and all were
deemed free and fair by international observers. Democratic laws and institutions were put in
place, an active media developed, and a small, but vocal civil society increasingly engages on the
political front. Similarly, in the past 18 years, Mongolia saw considerable success in moving from
a centrally-planned to a market-based economy.

8.       While Mongolia's political environment is dynamic and open, this has also brought its
own challenges to the process of governing, with three governments holding office in the last few
years A new bi-partisan coalition government was formed in the fall of 2008 following some
short-lived disturbances after the June 2008 parliamentary elections. Presidential elections were


at a low risk of debt distress, it will receive all its allocations in the form of credits unless its debt
sustainability position changes. Bank lending to Mongolia, currently on IDA-only terms, represents about
18 percent of the country's overall official development assistance flows (in 2008).
3See Annex 2 for the policy matrix.


                                                     2

held in May 2009, and the outcome could put strains on the bi-partisan coalition. However,
several observers estimate that the elections are unlikely to have an impact on the currently
existing bi-partisan consensus on, and commitment to, the reform efforts needed to deal with the
economic crisis.

9.       Major mineral deposits, including prospects in the Gobi region, when developed, have
the potential to significantly increase incomes and government revenues. But the risks of a
mineral-dependent economy have also been underscored by deficiencies in Mongolia's
management of the recent boom­which made it more difficult to adjust to the impact of the global
downturn. And as in most mineral-rich economies, managing the resource revenues consistently
and sustainably puts a high premium on governance reforms. The adjustments needed will take
place over the medium term, and include reforms that protect the poor, maintain critical
infrastructure, improve public investment decisions, restructure the banking sector, and resolve
key obstacles for mining and infrastructure development.


         III.      ECONOMIC CONTEXT AND MACROECONOMIC OUTLOOK


10.      Exacerbated by the slump in mineral prices, Mongolia has been one of the East Asian
economies hardest hit by the global downturn. While the government did save part of its mining
windfall during the "boom" years it also funded large increases in untargeted social expenditures,
wages and salaries, and poorly screened investment projects. When the "boom" turned into
"bust", the modest fiscal surplus quickly turned into a large deficit. At the same time, the current
account switched into deficit, and the financial sector, which had been overheating during the
boom period, ran into serious problems, with a major bank having to be put under
conservatorship. However, in response to the crisis, the government took a number of strong
policy actions, which led to an agreement with the IMF on a Stand-By Arrangement (SBA) and
laid the basis for this operation.

    A. Recent Economic Developments


11.      The global economic downturn was transmitted to the Mongolian economy
predominantly through the slump in mineral prices which returned the prices of Mongolia's main
exports back to their 2004 levels (Figure 1). In particular the price of copper fell 60 percent to
US$3500/tonne in March from US$8700/tonne in April 2008.




                                                3

      Figure 1. Global prices of Mongolia's main                       Figure 2. The current account turned into a
      exports have fallen back to their 2004 levels                      deficit in 2008, driven by the trade deficit

     Index=100 in January 2004                                         % of GDP




     Source: World Bank                                                Source: Bank of Mongolia and World Bank


     12.       The external shock aggravated pre-existing balance of payments pressures. Driven by
     large social transfers and consumption, domestic demand had outstripped GDP growth in the
     previous three years, leading to a deteriorating trade and current account balance. However, the
     added impact of lower commodity prices shifted the current account from a 6.7 percent of GDP
     surplus in 2007 to a 9.6 percent of GDP deficit in 2008 (Figure 2 and Table 1).

     13.       Mongolia is also facing a major slowdown in growth to an estimated 2.7 percent in 2009
     from 8.9 percent in 2008 (Table 1). This reflects developments in key sectors which have driven
     growth in recent years: agriculture, due to falling prices of cashmere and meat; transportation,
     storage and communication, due to weakening in the mining sector; and other services sectors
     (including retail and banking), which had been driven by large public expenditure increases on
     social transfers, and wages and salaries (Figure 3). Contributions to growth from the mining
     sector steadily declined since 2004. Recent monthly data show that while the contraction in
     mining output has stabilized, manufacturing output is still contracting sharply (Figure 4). In
     addition, formal unemployment has been rising since December 2008 while there is anecdotal
     evidence that real wages for unskilled informal labor have fallen sharply, based on recent
     informal market surveys. Furthermore, the prospects for a quick recovery are limited, with
     Mongolia's major export markets facing a prolonged slowdown.

                                                          2003        2004      2005     2006       2007      2008e   2009f

Fiscal policy

14.    During the "boom" years (2003-07), the government ran modest fiscal surpluses, but
these were insufficient to absorb the fiscal shock caused by the collapse of the mineral prices.
Moreover, the fiscal shock was exacerbated because, during the boom years, the government




                                                       5

shifted the fiscal burden away from the non-mining sector,4 leaving the budget increasingly
dependent on revenues from mining (see Table 2). At their peak, mining-related revenues, i.e.
corporate income tax and dividends from mining companies, the Windfall Profits Tax, and
royalties, contributed nearly 40 percent to total revenues.

15.      While before the boom years, social transfers had by and large been targeted to the poor,
thanks to buoyant revenues, these transfers proliferated and became universalized. Equally
problematic, the most important social transfer program, the Child Money Program, was largely
dependent on mining revenues: it received three quarters of its financing from the Mongolian
Development Fund (MDF), which in turn was financed by mineral revenue savings. Moreover,
wages and salaries as a share of GDP increased sharply from 2006 to 2008. And while capital
expenditure was increased, projects frequently lacked feasibility studies and insufficient resources
were set aside for the proper maintenance of existing infrastructure. As a result, the non-mining
fiscal deficit increased dramatically from a 7.3 percent deficit in 2006 to a 15.3 percent of GDP
deficit in 2008 (see Table 2).

16.      In the absence of sufficient fiscal surpluses from previous years, the government's fiscal
position became difficult once fiscal revenues declined as a result of the sharply lower
commodity prices. To keep the fiscal deficit within financeable limits, the government could cut
spending or raise revenues, or both. Since raising revenues is inherently difficult during an
economic downturn, the government had little choice but to cut spending drastically in its 2009
budget.

                                      Table 2. Fiscal developments

% of GDP, unless otherwise specified

                                               2003       2004       2005       2006       2007      2008e

     Windfall Profits Tax                        0.0        0.0        0.0       4.8         7.7        6.3
   Non-tax revenue                               7.0        5.5        5.0       6.1         7.5        4.0

   Current expenditure                         24.7       24.0        21.4      26.4        26.1      28.5

                                                      6

        17.      Even so, the original 2009 budget needed to be revised soon after it was adopted, due to
        overly optimistic revenue projections. The original 2009 budget was approved in November
        2008, but when the final 2008 budget outturn and the January and February 2009 figures came in,
        it became clear that the expected revenue estimate for the full year was unlikely to be realized
        (Figures 5a-c). Without additional measures, the 2009 budget deficit was heading for 12 percent
        of GDP.

        Financial sector

        18.      The global downturn aggravated problems in a financial sector which had been
        overheating during the boom years. During the boom, very high domestic inflation and loose
        monetary policies led to negative real interest rates on local currency deposits, leading to a flight
        of local currency savings into US dollar deposits. This was further aggravated by the BoM
        mopping up local currency as it sold off its international reserves in an attempt to hold on to a de
        facto currency peg to the USD. When a major bank failed in October 2008, and major shortages
        of foreign currency emerged--leading to a substantial deviation between the official Bank of
        Mongolia (BoM) exchange rate and the parallel market rate (Figure 6)5--the public started to lose
        confidence, leading to a flight of MNT, as well as USD deposits.




        5The word "parallel market" is a designation of the non-bank foreign exchange market. It does not imply
        any illegal activity.


                                                                   7

                           Figure 6. BoM and the parallel market rate

                 MNT per USD




                 Last observation: May 22, 2009.

                 Source: Mongolian Financial Association and World Bank


19.     The financial sector had gone through three distinct phases, starting in 2004 when the
commodity price boom began, and leading up to the recent stress in the financial sector. These
phases can be labeled as follows: sustainable growth, overheating, and loss of confidence.

20.     The first phase, from 2004 to mid-2007, was a period of sustainable growth of loans and
deposits. Commodity prices were beginning to rise. Narrow money and loans grew in line with
nominal GDP growth, non-performing loans (NPLs) were falling (as a share of total loans),
inflation was in single digits and the loans-to-deposits ratio was below 100 percent and stable.
From about 2006, the BoM started to peg the exchange rate to the USD, initially to avoid a strong
appreciation.

21.     Although new banks had been established in the years before, the banking sector was
relatively concentrated as a small number of large banks accounted for the majority of loans and
deposits. However, as a sign of trouble to come, a proliferation of unregulated and financially
weak savings and credit cooperatives led to the failure of 32 of them in 2006, affecting half of all
assets held at these institutions. The resolution of these failures took a long time, which led to
simmering popular distrust in the financial system. By 2007, there were 16 registered banks,
which accounted for 95 percent of total assets in the financial system. Ten were foreign owned.

22.     The second phase, from mid-2007 to mid-2008, exhibited the tell-tale signs of
overheating. Economic growth continued to be high, buoyed by still increasing commodity prices
(approaching their peak) and strong remittances inflows. Narrow money and loan growth started
to exceed nominal GDP growth and deposit growth. Increasingly, loans were directed to real
estate, construction and mortgage lending, leading to a feed-back cycle of rapidly growing
housing prices and more housing-related lending. Although NPLs started to increase, this was
masked by the strong loan growth. As the currency was effectively pegged, the pressure on the
balance of payments amplified due to high imports. Inflation accelerated to double digits. At its
peak it was the highest in the East Asian region and was accompanied by the emergence of
negative real interest rates on MNT deposits (Figure 7).




                                                     8

            Figure 7. Overheating: As inflation rose to a record high, the real
            interest rate on MNT deposits became strongly negative...

               % year-on-year change                % per annum (deflated by CPI inflation)




            Source: Bank of Mongolia and World Bank




    Figure 8. Overheating of the financial sector leads to loss of confidence in the MNT
               around mid-2008 resulting in flows out of MNT into FX deposits

      MNT billion, month-on-month change




    Source: Bank of Mongolia and World Bank



23.     The third phase started in mid-2008 with the collapse of commodity prices and would
lead to a loss of confidence. Growth had started to slow down, including in those countries
important for remittances to Mongolia. These remittances had traditionally supported real estate
investments, but now, their decrease led a housing price bust. Livestock-related prices such as
cashmere also dropped. A major bank failed, with exposure to other banks. The combined effect
was an increase in NPLs and loans with principal in arrears.



                                                   9

24.      Meanwhile, the pressure on the exchange rate kept growing due to a sudden drop in
export revenues, while imports kept rising. But whereas other major commodity exporters let
their currencies depreciate, Mongolia held on to its peg, leading to loss of US$500 million of
international reserves between July 2008 and February 2009. Despite this support, the currency
depreciated by about 38 percent between the end of October and the middle of March. The public
began to see the exchange rate movements as a one-way bet against the MNT, as pressure on the
exchange rate mounted. And as interest rates on US$ savings were as high as 12 to 18 percent in
some banks, while the real interest rate on MNT deposits was negative, MNT deposits were
converted into FX deposits (Figure 8), further fueling the depreciation of the MNT (Figure 9).
Finally, when the fourth largest bank failed, a general loss of confidence in the financial sector
occurred, leading to a general deposit flight.


                         Figure 9. Loss of confidence led to reserve losses, as
                           the BoM tried to defend the exchange rate peg

                         US$ million, month-on-month change      MNT per USD




                        * BoM and banking system's net international reserves.

                        Source: Bank of Mongolia and World Bank



Mining sector

25.      Finally, the collapse of mineral prices further depressed sentiment in an already downbeat
mining sector. A major shift in mining policy in 2006 had left Mongolia much less attractive for
mining investment. Parliament had adopted a Windfall Profits Tax (WPT) and introduced the
                                                                                     6

possibility of significant government equity participation of strategic deposits.7 Furthermore,
Parliament had held up approval over two mining project of global importance: the Oyu Tolgoi
(OT, copper and gold) and Tavan Tolgoi (TT, coal) agreements.

26.      Before this policy shift, Mongolia's 1997 Minerals Law was frequently credited with
helping to expand foreign investment in the mining sector and was regarded as among the best
mining laws in Asia and around the world. It established a legal framework for the mining sector


6A 68 percent tax applied to revenues from prices exceeding base prices of US$2600/tonne for copper and
US$500/ounce gold, which would be deposited in the MDF to finance social programs and infrastructure.
7No less than 50 percent for strategic deposits explored with state resources and no less than 34 percent in
other strategic deposits.


                                                     10

that sought to promote private sector participation and FDI. Provisions included first-come, first-
served license application and granting procedures, security of tenure for licensees, regulatory
guidance for environmental protection and obligations for licensees, and provisions for the
assignment and transfer of mineral licenses. When mineral prices started to rise, FDI took off
sharply (Figure 10a). As soon as prices came down, investment started to level off, illustrating the
volatility and instability in the sector created by the policy instability (Figure 10b).


     Figure 10a. FDI inflows have risen                Figure 10b. ... although it seems to be
                  recently....                                               leveling off

US$ billion                                            US$ billion, 4-quarter rolling sum(1)




Source: Bank of Mongolia                               (1) Sum over previous four quarters to adjust for seasonal
                                                       effects.

                                                       Source: Bank of Mongolia and World Bank


27.      In conclusion, Mongolia was hit hard by the crisis, because the global downturn
accentuated inherent weaknesses in several key areas: fiscal policy and management, social
protection, and the financial sector. In addition, the mineral price shock accentuated the
uncertainty, which had been created earlier in the key sector to lead the recovery--the mining
sector.

    B. Macroeconomic Outlook and Debt Sustainability


28.      With the sharp drop in the global economy and in the economies of Mongolia's trading
partners, the medium-term outlook has deteriorated markedly and become uncertain. With
forecasts trending toward an increasingly deep and prolonged global recession, Mongolia's small,
export-oriented economy is particularly vulnerable to further external shocks. Real GDP growth
is forecast to drop to 2-3 percent in 2009, down from an average of over 9 percent from 2004-08,
as global export demand (in particular from China), private consumption and FDI inflows are
projected to fall.

29.      Faced with the reality of the global downturn and its impact on Mongolia, the
government initially considered a variety of possible responses, including signing long-term
mineral export contracts in exchange for large up-front payments, and implementing a wide-
ranging stimulus package to be funded by a US$1.2 billion sovereign bond. However, as adverse
conditions continued to worsen, a bi-partisan consensus began to emerge around a more
comprehensive policy response, which could be supported by the IMF and other development
partners. These policy changes included strong actions on fiscal, monetary, financial and
exchange rate policies. In March 2009, based on this demonstrated commitment to policy reform,


                                                   11

IMF staff successfully concluded negotiations on a program--the first of its kind in East Asia
since the 1997/98 financial crisis.

30.      Government's commitment was demonstrated by the strength of the corrective actions
taken during the first quarter of 2009. On the fiscal side, Parliament approved, with bi-partisan
support, an amended budget which brought the runaway fiscal deficit back to 5.4 percent of GDP,
consistent with a reduction of the non-mining deficit by 5 percent of GDP in 2009 compared to
2008 outturn. On monetary and exchange rate policies, the BoM raised its policy rate from 9.75
to 14 percent, and started auctioning foreign exchange. And on the financial sector side, an
international auditor was appointed to assess the financial situation of the failed bank.

31.      On April 1, 2009, the IMF Board approved an 18-month SBA of US$229 million. The
choice of the non-concessional, shorter term instrument (repayment in four years with two years
grace) of an SBA over the concessional Poverty Reduction Grant Facility (PGRF) or the
Exogenous Shock Facility (ESF) was justified by the IMF's assessment of a severe, but short
term, balance of payments problem.8 In the case of Mongolia, the extraordinary external shock
coming from the collapse of copper prices created a balance of payments deficit too large to be
financed under either the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) or the ESF. Under the
SBA, however, Mongolia benefits from exceptional access to IMF resources (300 percent of
quota). Mongolia qualified for such access, based on four criteria: (i) exceptional balance of
payments pressures; (ii) high probability that debt remains sustainable; (iii) good prospects for
regaining access to private markets; and (iv) a policy program which provides a reasonably strong
prospect of success.

32.      The main objective of the SBA is to help Mongolia adjust to the shock coming from the
global financial crisis by stabilizing the macroeconomic situation. The center piece is a
substantial fiscal adjustment to deal with the fall in mineral revenues of 10 percent of GDP. Even
after this adjustment, fiscal deficits of 6 and 4 percent of GDP, in 2009 and 2010, respectively,
have been built into the program, amounting to a total financing gap of US$205 million over
2009 and 2010 (Tables 3 and 4). The other building blocks of the SBA are (i) a combination of
monetary and exchange rate policies which would lower inflation and maintain a flexible
exchange rate; (ii) a rebuilding of confidence in the banking sector; and (iii) the protection of the
most vulnerable from the downturn and the adjustments.

33.      Bank staff participated in the IMF missions that prepared the program. The shared
assessment was that the cost of not having a program would be more severe than the risk
involved. The outflow of local currency deposits would likely continue and fiscal pressures would
lead to cash flow problems, resulting in wage and pension debts. Without a solid program, the
government would be forced to monetize the deficit leading to high inflation, while creating
distortions through parallel exchange rates and rationing of foreign currency in order to protect
reserves. The social consequences of such an economic unwinding would be severe.




8Under the PRGF, a country that has a comprehensive country-owned Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
may borrow up to 140 percent of its IMF quota under a three-year arrangement (185 percent under
exceptional circumstances), see http://www.imf.org/external/np/exr/facts/prgf.htm. The ESF is an
additional facility for PGRF-eligible countries; however access is limited to 75 percent of its quota. See
http://www.imf.org/external/np/exr/facts/esf.htm.


                                                   12

                       Table 3. External financing requirements and sources

               US$ million
                                                                              2009f        2010f
               Gross financing requirement                                    1,291        1,195
                    Current account deficit                                     502          499
                    Amortization of medium- and long-term debt                   93           54
                    Gross reserve accumulation                                  165          253
                    Other items                                                 531          389
               Available financing                                            1,007        1,042
                    Grants                                                      240          230
                    Disbursements to public sector                               96          144
                    Disbursements to private sector                             355          337
                    Foreign direct investment                                   317          330
               Financing need                                                   284          153
                    IMF SBA                                                     139           93
                    Donor support requested                                     145           60

             Source: IMF (2009)


                        Table 4. Fiscal financing requirements and sources

              MNT billion unless otherwise specified
                                                                   2008       2009f      2010f
               Balance
                    Total revenues and grants                     2,156        1,936     2,269
                    Total expenditure and net lending             2,462        2,316     2,559

                         (% of GDP)                                 -5.0         -6.0       -4.0
               Financing                                            305          390        290
                    Foreign (net)                                     43          53        150
                    Domestic (net)                                  262          101         40

                         (US$ million*)                                0         151         67

              * Assuming exchange rate of MNT 1500 per USD.

              Source: IMF (2009)


34.      The IMF program was approved under the assumption that the financing gap would be
met by other development partners. To fill the gap, the ADB, Japan and the World Bank made
firm pledges amounting to US$170 million. Several other donors have indicated that they are
preparing to meet the residual financing need for 2009 and 2010. Potential co-financing from
Australia amounting to AUD 5 million (US$3.5 million) and provision of TA by Korea are
expected to support this program. This operation will help crowd in these resources, and ensure a
fully financed program. To mitigate any risk of a financing gap, IMF staff will assess the
availability of financing by the time of the first review in June 2009 and adjust program targets
accordingly if needed. Although the program leaves room for a US$200 million non-concessional
loan, the IMF notes that this will be very difficult under current market conditions. In addition,
such borrowing would have to be consistent with debt sustainability and non-concessional
borrowing limits under the program, and the proceeds should go towards further building
international reserves.9


9As an aside, Mongolia is not subject to IDA's Non-concessional Borrowing Policy, because it has not
benefitted from the Multilateral Debt Relief Initiative, nor is it eligible for IDA grants, due its low risk of
debt distress.


                                                      13

35.      Jointly, the IMF and the World Bank also updated the debt sustainability analysis
(DSA).10 It showed that Mongolia was at low risk of external debt distress.11 While the debt ratios
would rise significantly over the next two years, because the government would receive front-
loaded foreign financing to recover from major terms of trade shock, the debt outlook would
recover and improve over the medium term. Key medium-term risks involve large debt service in
2012-15 associated with the repayments to the IMF under the SBA.

36.      The baseline macroeconomic framework takes into consideration the impact of the
substantial fiscal adjustment for 2009-10, but assumes that the economy would return to
sustained growth over the medium term, underpinned by a major mining project. The fiscal
deficit is projected to be 6 percent of GDP in deficit in 2009, as budgeted expenditure has been
adjusted downward to 36.8 percent of GDP in line with the expected reduction in revenue to 30.8
percent of GDP (mainly due to the drop in mining revenues). The deficit is projected to narrow to
4 percent of GDP in 2010, as revenue is expected to pick up, due to growth recovering slightly,
while expenditure is cut further. Assuming the mining development is well-managed and comes
on stream in 2013, both the current account and the fiscal balance are expected to receive a boost
and jump into a prolonged surplus.

37.      The medium-term baseline projection is based on the following assumptions. After a
slowdown in 2009, growth will gradually recover and rebound to 11 percent supported by the
development of the major copper mining project, which will start exports in 2013 and also boost
fiscal revenues. The current account deficit is expected to amount to 6.5 percent of GDP in 2009,
and will remain in deficit until 2012 due to large imports of mining-related investment goods.
After that point, the current account should jump to a substantial surplus in 2013 as mining
exports increase. Inflation is projected to slow to about 5 percent over the medium term.
Expenditures are expected to decline steadily as a share of GDP. Finally, it is assumed that
Mongolia would become eligible for non-concessional borrowing from both the International
Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and the ADB in 2013, as the mining projects
come on stream. Capital inflows, private external debt and portfolio investment, (which have all
been negligible so far), in addition to FDI, are expected to increase, in line with developments of
mining projects, and substantially help to sustain growth and build international reserves.

38.      Under this scenario, Mongolia's external debt dynamics are at low risk of debt distress,
even though the country's risk has increased considerably (compared to the 2008 DSA) due to a
sharp deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook. Borrowing under the SBA and other donor
financing would increase debt ratios only during the next three years, and would be offset by
Mongolia's substantial mineral wealth potential. Even in a scenario of a significant depreciation
of the currency, external debt rises initially, but is brought steadily downward over time. If a
prudent policy stance is maintained, and a significant portion of the mineral-related flows is
saved, Mongolia would end up as a net external creditor by 2029. If Mongolia manages its
existing debt well and contracts new debt prudently, it should be able to ride out the effects of the
adverse commodity shock and move to a new medium-term development path underpinned by
the commodity sector (see Table 5). This scenario would improve even further if negotiations on
a coal mine12 are concluded as well, which will lead to larger projected FDI inflows in the short
term and export receipts in the medium term.

39.      In the longer run, Mongolia will need to focus on the diversification of its economy, and
remove the binding constraints on growth. Even though Mongolia's mining sector will remain a

10See Annex 5 for the medium-term baseline projection, key assumptions, stress tests and alternative
scenarios.
11Mongolia has an insignificant amount of domestic debt.
12The Tavan Tolgoi deposit is one of the largest undeveloped coal deposits in the world.


                                                   14

dominant source of its economic growth for some time to come, the economic strategy should
create the conditions for economic diversification. Given the typical strength of the currency of a
minerals-based economy, a strategy based on labor-intensive exports is unlikely to be successful.
Instead, maximizing the chances of success across a wide range of potential economic growth
opportunities by investing in general infrastructure and education seems a more promising
approach. In this regard, removing the currently binding constraints associated with infrastructure
bottlenecks, distortionary taxes, lack of trade and logistics coordination internally and
internationally, growing corruption, inadequate contract enforcement, and the high cost of capital
are the most urgent.13 Investing in physical and human capital, while alleviating these binding
constraints, will yield expected outcomes in terms of improving returns to private sector
activities, give firms the opportunity to "innovate" into new products and markets, and into
higher-value-added products. Together with improving governance (often a key challenge for
mineral-rich economies), such a strategy holds the promise of achieving high and sustained
broad-based economic growth over the long term.

                               Table 5. Medium-term baseline projection

                                                             2008e   2009f  2010f  2011f    2012f

(1) Based on GDP deflator. (2) Public and publicly guaranteed debt.

Source: World Bank/IMF (2009), World Bank


40.      However, there are also considerable downside risks, both in the short as well as the long
run. An increasingly deep and prolonged global recession, a prolonged slump of copper prices, or
a significant delay in the development of major mining projects will lead to reduced mineral
revenues and negatively impact growth, the current account and the fiscal balance. In particular,
the impact of the copper price staying 20 percent below the already conservative baseline


13World Bank (2007a).


                                                        15

scenario of a slow recovery, would increase Mongolia's debt stock indicator above the debt
threshold. This shows that Mongolia remains vulnerable to changes in commodity prices, despite
the substantial increase in export volumes that are expected from the development of the OT
(Oyu Tolgoi) mineral project. Part of this risk will be mitigated if the TT negotiations would also
be concluded successfully in a timely fashion.

41.      Populist pressures could lead to sub-optimal policy actions. Populist pressures could
derail the fiscal, monetary and exchange-rate policy reforms needed to contain the crisis, leading
to a further worsening of the economic situation. And pressures to spend its way out of the crisis
could lead Mongolia to agree to sub-optimal mineral export contracts or non-concessional
financing that negatively impacts debt sustainability. Finally, another risk is that the commitment
to structural reforms could wane if the copper price rebounds substantially, and leave Mongolia
as vulnerable to the next commodity price downturn as it was now.

42.      In conclusion, the macroeconomic policy framework currently in place is adequate and
sustainable for the purposes of the proposed DPC, with important downside risks, but
considerable risks exist. If the country is able to manage the downturn and uses this opportunity
to strengthen economic management, Mongolia could emerge out of the crisis with a stronger
economic and fiscal policy framework than the one with which it entered the crisis. Under the
program supported by the multilateral institutions, fiscal policies would become more sustainable
with the adoption of fiscal rules to limit expenditures and public debt, while enforcing savings
during boom years; social transfers would become considerably more efficient in reducing
poverty; the financial sector would benefit from consolidation and better supervision; and the
mining     sector   would      benefit   from     a   more     competitive     policy    framework.




                                                 16

   IV.      THE GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAM AND PARTICIPATORY PROCESSES


43.      Since the beginning of 2009, the government has taken strong actions on fiscal, monetary
and exchange rate policies to address the crisis.14 On fiscal policy, Parliament approved an
amended 2009 budget projecting a 5.4 percent of GDP deficit in March 2009, mainly by cutting
expenditures. On the exchange rate and monetary policy, the BoM raised the policy rate to allow
a more flexible exchange rate (initially through an auction), while avoiding overshooting and
preserving its foreign exchange reserves (see Table 6).


                     Table 6. Summary of policy actions and expected impact

      Government policy action                                   Expected impact
 BoM raised the policy rate                 Avoid overshooting of exchange rate; preserve FX
                                            reserves; restore confidence in the tugrug
 Public investment cut                      Curtail poorly planned and low-priority new investments,
                                            and projects unlikely to be implemented this fiscal year due
                                            to lack of absorption capacity
 Expenditure cut on wages and salaries of   Save on excessive bonuses, and stop rapidly growing civil
 public servants; hiring freeze imposed     service
 Interest payments on foreign loans cut     Constrain recourse to non-concessional foreign borrowing
 Universal social transfers cut             Target social transfers towards the poor
 FX auction introduced                      Move to more flexible exchange rate and improve
                                            transparency of FX allocation
 International reputable auditor for failed Set standard for dealing with future bank failures
 bank
 BoM increased capital adequacy             Strengthen capital base of those banks who are able to meet
 requirements                               the higher requirements; encourages banks to address their
                                            portfolio quality issues and reduce weight of riskier assets in
                                            portfolio
 BoM revised and clarified deposit          Avoid abuse and unnecessary fiscal costs; strengthen public
 guarantee law                              confidence in deposit guarantee

Source: Mongolian authorities, World Bank



44.      The main amendments to the 2009 budget included substantial expenditure cuts relative
to the approved 2009 budget (Table 7). First, public investment was cut by MNT 127 billion.
Low-priority new investments, projects for which bidding had not started, and projects for which
no feasibility studies had been conducted were excluded. Second, expenditure on wages and
salaries of public servants was cut by MNT 12 billion and a hiring freeze imposed. Third,
projected interest payments on foreign loans were reduced and are now estimated at MNT 51
billion. This would allow Mongolia only to borrow up to US$50 million on commercial terms
under current market conditions.




14Previously existing government programs, such as the 2008-12 Government Action Plan and the
National Development Strategy, were largely overtaken by events. Even an Anti-Crisis Action Plan
approved in late 2008 is now being reviewed and modified to ensure its appropriateness for the rapidly
changing economic and financial context.


                                                   17

                         Table 7. Selected components of the general budget

                                                   2008 outturn     Approved 2009           Amended 2009
                                                                         budget                  budget

      (% of GDP)                                             35.2                  34.3                  31.3

      (% of GDP)                                             40.2                  40.4                  36.8

      (% of GDP)                                            -15.3                 -11.7                 -10.4

(1) According to 2008 amended budget.

Source: Mongolian authorities, World Bank calculations


45.      Whereas the amended 2009 budget makes substantial real cuts in total expenditures (of
about 16 percent, compared to 2008), it allows for a significant overall real increase in transfers
(of nearly 10 percent). This category includes intergovernmental transfers (to finance local
government deficits), pensions and social transfers. Wages and salaries see a small reduction in
real terms. The bulk of the reduction in expenditures comes from domestic public investment, and
purchases of goods and services (Table 8).



                         Table 8. Public expenditure trends (2008 and 2009)

                                             % yoy nominal change               % yoy real change

                                              2008            2009             2008               2009
                                             outturn        amended           outturn          amended
                                                             budget                             budget
 Total expenditure and net lending                  40.6           -6.0              13.8            -16.1
 Purchases of goods and services                    27.2          -28.8               0.4            -38.9
 Wages and salaries                                 85.7            7.9              58.9              -2.2
 Transfers                                          27.6           19.6                0.7              9.5
 Domestic investment                                23.3          -24.2              -3.5            -34.3

Note: Real change based on nominal change deflated by year-average CPI inflation: 26.8 percent in 2008 and 10.1
      percent in 2009.

Source: Ministry of Finance and World Bank




                                                      18

46.      The Child Money Program saw an important change in its financing. Three quarters of its
financing will come from the savings in the MDF, financed by mining revenues. This allowed a
budget reduction of the universal social transfers by 33 percent (MNT 47 billion out of MNT 142
billion). However, there was no attempt, in this amendment at least, to target these transfers to the
poor. This makes the program very much dependent on the mineral revenues, which is not
optimal, in particular not during the current downturn. The introduction of targeting is urgently
needed, so that the poor can be better protected from the downturn. In June, Parliament is
expected to discuss new amendments to the 2009 budget, which would include steps to
consolidate the various welfare programs, make them easier to administer, make them more
predictable for the Mongolian households, and avoid overlap of payments.

47.      To restore confidence in the tugrug, the BoM raised its key policy rate to 14 percent from
9.75 percent on March 11. This move signals the BoM's intention to bring the tugrug real interest
rates back to positive levels.15 The extent of the move was aimed to change the public's
expectations, in particular the one-way bet against the domestic currency. Changing these
expectations will prevent the exchange rate from overshooting and preserves international
reserves, as the BoM allows the exchange rate to adjust more flexibly, initially through an auction
system. Hence, since March 31, the BoM has started to buy and sell FX reserves via an auction
and published the results on its website. Compared to the administrative rationing in place before,
this has also greatly improved transparency.

48.      In addition to the raising of the policy rate and the introduction of a foreign exchange
auction, the BoM took several other steps to restore confidence. First, the BoM appointed an
international reputable auditor to undertake a portfolio audit and develop a restructuring plan for
the failed bank. This also will help to set new standards in dealing with future bank failures, if
any. Second, the BoM increased the capital adequacy requirements for commercial banks from 10
to 12 percent by the end of 2009. This is a check on the commitment of owners of the banks and
the resource mobilization capacity of each bank. It also strengthens the capital base of those
banks who are able to meet the higher requirements, and encourages the banks to address their
portfolio quality issues and reduce the weight of the riskier assets in their portfolio. Third, the
BoM revised and clarified the deposit guarantee law to cover current accounts, savings accounts,
time deposits and interbank deposits. To prevent abuse and unnecessary fiscal costs, deposits of
"related parties" and those of holders of subordinated debt were excluded. The deposit guarantee
law was instated in November 2008 to stop the deposit flight, but it had left many customers in
uncertainty about which deposits were included.

49.      Building on the momentum created by these corrective measures, the government has
also begun to outline the main policy actions of an indicative medium-term economic strategy.
This emerging framework takes off from the government's short-term plan of action for the next
18 months, which is consistent with the IMF agreement and the on-going dialogue with the key
development partners who are planning to provide budget support. At the external development
partners' conference held on March 14, 2009, the minister of finance presented the most recent
medium-term thinking within government in the following areas: (i) fiscal sustainability; (ii)
social protection; (iii) restoring confidence in the financial sector; and (iv) mining development.

50.      To avoid a repeat of the "boom-and-bust" spending pattern that Mongolia has just
experienced, the government plans to submit to Parliament a draft law on Fiscal Responsibility in
2009. This law will ensure that mining revenues are better managed in the future. Another
objective will be to improve the planning and budgeting for public investments. Similarly, the
budget amendment's exclusion of non-priority projects and projects without feasibility studies


15As inflation fell to 12 percent year on year in April, the policy rate is now just positive in real terms.


                                                     19

will set the tone for a considerable strengthening of the procedures to select and develop
investment projects to be financed by the state budget. Finally, it will prioritize the protection of
infrastructure maintenance--critical during the downturn.

51.      The medium­term goal of the envisaged reforms with respect to social transfers is to
better protect the poor by targeting the currently untargeted grants (in particular, the Child Money
Program). During 2009, the government will propose to Parliament legislation which will
consolidate several existing social transfer programs into one social protection program and
reintroduce targeting. Work will also start on establishing an improved proxy-means test (PMT)
and a national beneficiary database. To better track the impact of the new social protection
program, the Bank will assist the government to design and implement an impact evaluation. The
goal will be to gradually improve the PMT-based targeting, so that by December 2010, the
beneficiary database has been completed at the national level.

52.      In the financial sector, the objective is to ensure its continued stability by intensifying
supervision and taking decisive action in case of bank failures in order to retain confidence in the
financial sector. In addition, a restructuring of the banking sector is envisaged, supported by a
well-sequenced increase of paid-in capital of commercial banks.

53.      Indicative medium-term reforms in the mining sector have as their objective to improve
the legal environment, sector policies, and increase the number of skilled Mongolians in the
workforce. Based on the recent experience gained during the negotiations of a major investment
agreement, the government will develop and adopt draft model investment agreements, which
future negotiations can use as their starting point. New regulations will also be issued to improve
the functioning of the mining cadastre by the Cabinet. By 2011, the goal is to have mining
projects follow responsible mining practices. Adherence to this regulatory framework will be
monitored strictly, using enhanced regulatory capacity. In order to increase the employment for
the Mongolian workforce in mining, the government will substantially increase the number of
Mongolians to be trained in the relevant mining skills.

54.      In conclusion, the government's short-term plan of action for the next 18 months is clear.
It is based on the agreement with the IMF and dialogue with key development partners planning
to provide budget support. Using the short-term corrective measures already taken and envisaged
as stepping stones, the government has started to outline a longer-term agenda for economic
policy focused on restoring the goal of fostering sustainable, shared growth.




             V.      BANK SUPPORT TO THE GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAM


     A. Link to the proposed Interim Strategy Note (ISN)

55.      Given the economic crisis, far-advanced preparations for a new Country Partnership
Strategy (CPS) were deferred in early 2009 in favor of a recently approved Interim Strategy to
provide a bridging framework for an 18-month period until economic conditions stabilize. The
Interim Strategy positions the Bank to support the government in addressing urgent crisis needs
and easing the fiscal adjustment, but also to support renewed efforts to make reforms that will
reduce the impact of future shocks. As conditions stabilize and there is a clearer planning horizon,
a four-year CPS will be prepared, supporting Mongolia's medium-term agenda.

56.      Under the Interim Strategy, the majority of new IDA resources will be shifted from
previously planned investment projects to DPCs. Two single-tranche DPCs (US$40 million in


                                                 20

FY10 and US$20 million in FY11), totaling SDR 40 million and representing two-thirds of the
notional IDA 15 envelope of SDR 60 million,16 are envisaged. They will support key policy
reforms to improve macro and fiscal sustainability in a mineral-based economy, protect the poor
and vulnerable, restore confidence in the financial sector, and encourage transparent and prudent
mining investments and a more competitive and stable medium-term business investment climate.
Active projects and analytical work are also being realigned, as appropriate, to support these
policy reforms (see Section D below). The Interim Strategy envisaged the current, first DPC of
US$40 million equivalent to target the key crisis areas (fiscal policy and management, social
protection, and the financial sector) and the mining sector, which will be important for medium-
term recovery.

    B. Consultations held in preparation for the proposed operation

57.     The policy measures supported in this proposed operation are informed by an intensive
consultation process involving key stakeholders. The main activities included:

    ·   Mongolia: Mining and Infrastructure Conference, Apr 13 - 14, 2009. The event
        brought parliament members, government officials, private sector representatives, civil
        society organizations, and external partners together to exchange ideas about how best to
        develop the mining sector in a sustainable manner, and to deliver the infrastructure
        needed to support mining activities. International experts included Mr. Eduardo Anina
        (former Finance Minister of Chile), who shared his country's experience in prudently
        managing mining revenues.

    ·   Government of Mongolia-External Partners Meeting, Apr 7, 2009. At this meeting,
        attended by the prime minister, cabinet ministers, parliamentarians and the full economic
        team, the minister of finance and the governor of the BoM presented the government's
        response to the crisis, and outlined elements of a medium-term agenda.

    ·   Public Expenditure and Financial Management Review dissemination, Feb 3-5, 2009.
        The report was launched at the Academy of Management. The findings of the PEFMR
        were presented and discussed in a series of four policy debates--fiscal and public
        financial management, social protection, health, and education--with the participation of
        key stakeholders, including the deputy minister for finance, the minister of social welfare
        and labor, the deputy minister of health, and the minister of education, culture and
        science. The meetings were used as platforms for discussing immediate policy actions
        necessary in the context of the current economic downturn. Main discussion topics
        pertained to the severe economic downturn faced by Mongolia, what to do about it, and
        how expenditures should be prioritized. Selected media were invited to attend these
        policy debates.

    ·   Mongolia Economic Policy Conference, Oct 28, 2008. The objectives of the conference
        were to discuss the opportunities and challenges of mineral-rich economies. The
        conference was organized by the government and the World Bank Group, and attended
        by a wide range of senior policy makers and experts, including the president, the prime
        minister and the minister of finance. Justin Yifu Lin, Chief Economist of the World
        Bank; Yegor Gaidar, former Prime Minister of Russia; and Professor Richard Pomfret
        delivered key note speeches.

    ·   Economic Updates. In response to public demand, the Bank increased the frequency of
        the Economic Updates from quarterly to monthly. The October 2008 Quarterly stressed
        the negative impact of the global slowdown on the fiscal and current deficits. The


16About US$60 million and about US$90 million respectively at the present exchange rate.


                                                21

        February 2009 Quarterly honed in on the policy options available to the government. The
        April monthly focused on the actions taken by the government. These updates received
        widespread attention and appreciation, by the press and key policy makers.

    ·   Policy dialogue with government and Parliament. At every stage during the
        preparation of this operation, the Bank team has had intensive dialogue with senior policy
        makers and key members of parliament on the government's evolving action plan in light
        of the deteriorating economic situation. This iterative process resulted in strong
        ownership and full transparency on the contents of the proposed DPC.

    C. Collaboration with the IMF and Other Donors


58.     The partnership between the IMF and the Bank in the preparation of the SBA has been
very strong and complementary. Bank staff participated in all IMF missions, leading up to the
SBA Board approval. A joint IMF/Bank mission was also undertaken to Japan to ensure proper
coordination with the authorities there (see Annex 4 for the draft indicative IMF/World Bank
policy matrix).

59.     Collaboration with the ADB has been equally strong, in particular in the area of social
protection. A joint team of the ADB and the World Bank is currently assisting the government
with key reforms in its social welfare system in order to better protect the poor during the
downturn. The IMF and the World Bank, with ADB participation, also conducted an updated debt
sustainability analysis.

60.     The Mongolian government's Letter of Intent to the IMF recognizes the joint assistance
of the IMF, the ADB and the World Bank in support of the following key policy reforms:

    1. Strengthening the institutional framework for fiscal policy to prevent the repeat of the
        boom and bust cycles of recent years and ensure the long-term sustainability of its
        policies by submitting a Fiscal Responsibility Law to Parliament (supported by IMF and
        World Bank assistance).

    2. Overhauling its social transfer programs, improving targeting and raising the level of
        social support to the very poor (supported by IMF, ADB and World Bank assistance).

    3. Further strengthening of the banking system by improving the current framework for
        deposit guarantees and enhancing bank supervision (with IMF and World Bank
        assistance).

    D. Relationship to other Bank operations


61.     Under the World Bank Group's Interim Strategy, the existing loan portfolio is being
redirected and disbursements accelerated to address short-term crisis needs. The portfolio is
strongly focused on improving the livelihoods of the poor, both in the rural as well as in the urban
areas.

62.     The Sustainable Livelihoods Project II and International Finance Corporation (IFC)
investments will continue to expand rural access to microcredit and other financial services, in
coordination with commercial banks, NBFIs,17 and other external partners. Additional finance is
being sought to ensure sustainability and expand geographic coverage of the ongoing Index-
Based Livestock Insurance Project, an innovative pilot project that is introducing market-based


17Non-bank financial institution.


                                                22

insurance products to herders that provide coverage in the event of catastrophic weather events.
Additional finance would allow livestock insurance to be introduced in more provinces, build the
necessary institutional framework to sustain the insurance, and pre-finance an important potential
government liability that insures herders against major natural disasters. An amendment to the
insurance law which would allow banks to become insurance agents and provide an integrated
package of credit and insurance to herders, could be supported in a second DPC.

63.       To help vulnerable populations in Ulaanbaatar, with an emphasis on peri-urban ger18 area
residents, activities include additional financing of an ongoing Energy Project to support urgent
maintenance of Ulaanbaatar's antiquated electricity distribution infrastructure -- a priority also
supported under the DPC's focus on ensuring budget allocations to the maintenance of key
infrastructure.

64.       The ambitious policy reform agenda envisaged under the ISN and its DPCs will also
require considerable capacity-building, together with targeted, just-in-time technical assistance,
and stepped-up efforts at public outreach and dialogue. The ISN supports these activities as
follows:
    ·     Current technical assistance projects (GAP, ECTAC, Mining TA) are being adjusted to
          link with the policy reform agenda supported by the DPC, drawing on findings under the
          recently completed Public Expenditure and Financial Management Review (World Bank,
          2009b) and other studies. In addition, a new technical assistance (TA) support program is
          being developed to support the policy reforms on social protection. The Bank will also
          step up support to government's efforts to increase budget transparency, including in
          implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI).19

    ·     The Mining TA and Governance Partnership Facility (GPF) will strengthen government
          and independent capacity for mining and related economic policy analysis. The ongoing
          Mining TA will also support development of governance, financial and fiduciary
          arrangements for the Erdenes state holding company consistent with corporate
          governance principles.

    ·     A statistical capacity building project, under preparation in parallel to this DPC, can
          improve the quality of key statistical systems and strengthen targeting of development
          resources, critical to the enhanced economic statistics needed to manage the current
          downturn.

    ·     The GPF grant will support the policy reform agenda through financing independent
          analysis, public outreach on select policy issues, and introduction of demand-side tools to
          foster transparency and accountability.

    ·     Finally, the Bank Group will also support enhanced capacity in the BoM, Ministry of
          Finance (MoF), Prime Minister's Office, and the newly formed National Development
          and Innovation Committee to help strengthen implementation of the government's reform
          program.

    ·     Potential co-financing from Australia amounting to AUD 5 million (US$3.5 million) and
          provision of TA by Korea are expected to support this program.


18A ger is the traditional dwelling tent of the Mongolian people.
19The EITI program is meant to strengthen governance by improving transparency and accountability in
the extractives sector through the publication of private companies' payments and the disclosure of
government's receipts of oil, gas and mining. Mongolia is about to complete its second reconciliation report
since it joined EITI in 2006. It has been identified as one of four countries in line to be declared as "EITI
compliant" following an independent validation.


                                                     23

65.     The IFC addresses the current weaknesses in the financial markets and real sectors
through investment and advisory service programs. This work includes: (i) providing technical
assistance to BoM and banks on strategies and methods of dealing with the financial crisis,
including NPL management and increasing liquidity; (ii) collaborating with other international
financial institutions to address specific capital requirements of the banking system; (iii)
developing the non-bank financial sector including leasing; (iv) addressing liquidity needs of
investment clients; (v) identifying opportunities to invest in import substitution industries, in
particular aiming at food security and quality; (vi) improving inspection regimes and corporate
governance to increase efficiency and improve market practice; and (vii) creating opportunities
for Mongolia to participate in IFC's crisis response facilities, including bank capitalization, trade
finance, and microfinance liquidity. IFC investments in the real sector will help diversify
Mongolia's economic base.

66.     The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) will also continue to supplement
the work of the Bank and the IFC by offering its guarantee product in support of private
investment into the country.

     E. Performance & Key Lessons Learned


67.     Mongolia has had limited experience with policy-based lending. Two operations
(Economic Transition Support Credit 20 and the Banking and Enterprise Sector Adjustment
Credit21) were approved in the early/mid 1990s and the Financial Sector Adjustment Credit22 was
approved in 2000. A planned series of single-tranche programmatic Structural Adjustment Loans,
envisaged in the April 2004 Country Assistance Strategy never materialized. In June 2004, the
first Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC) under this series was withdrawn after negotiations
and prior to Board consideration because of concerns, shared by the IMF, which let its PRGF
lapse in parallel, about the non-transparent nature of decisions taken on rescheduling of Russian
debt to Mongolia. A Quality Assurance Group Learning Review later concluded that this was a
highly appropriate decision. The dialogue on a possible PRSC was pursued until September 2005,
when it was replaced by a TA operation (the Governance Assistance Project).

68.     Although these operations were implemented under greatly differing situations, a number
of lessons remain valid and this operation's design has benefitted from them:

     ·  Continuing commitment, support and ownership from the senior leadership in the
        government are needed during project preparation and implementation, in particular
        when there are changes in the administration. Consequently, during the preparation of
        this operation, dialogue was continuously and systematically pursued with senior
        policymakers of both coalition parties.
