     ·  The weak capacity and lack of information sharing among government agencies requires
        more awareness-raising seminars and workshops for senior and mid-level officials for
        policy changes to increase ownership. Section V.B above lists the various activities used
        to raise such awareness during the preparation of this DPC.

     ·  Technical assistance operations and capacity building programs are necessary to both
        prepare the ground for and support implementation of adjustment operations. Three
        existing operations have been restructured to focus directly on the policy areas covered in
        the DPC. A new TA support program on social protection is being developed.


20 World Bank (1997).
21 World Bank (1999).
22 World Bank (2005).


                                                24

    ·   Timing is important for the institutional-building components, especially in countries
        with weak civil service such as Mongolia. The time needed to introduce fundamental
        changes, as well as build improved institutions, require careful programming and
        sequencing. The combination and sequencing of policy-lending and TA projects under
        the Interim Strategy, followed by a medium-term assistance strategy to build and deepen
        the reforms, attempts to operationalize this particular lesson.

    ·   Donor coordination is essential to ensure the rehabilitation of key sectors, especially
        where individual donor resources are limited. Close cooperation between donors in
        Mongolia clearly enhances synergy. During preparation, the government and the
        multilateral and bilateral development partners have worked closely and jointly to
        coordinate their support to the policy reform agenda.

    F. Analytical Underpinnings


69.     The proposed DPC can fortunately draw on a wealth of recently conducted analytical
work on fiscal policy and management (including reform and infrastructure), social protection,
the financial sector, the mining sector and governance.23

    ·   The fiscal policy and management agenda is underpinned by the 2009 World Bank Public
        Expenditure and Financial Management Review, the 2008 World Bank Governance
        Assessment Report, a series of studies on improving medium-term program budgeting
        undertaken under an existing TA project (the ECTAC project), the 2008 IMF report on
        "Budget Preparation: A Roadmap for Institutional Strengthening", and the 2007 World
        Bank report "Foundation for Sustainable Development: Rethinking the Delivery of
        Infrastructure Services in Mongolia". These studies highlight the weaknesses in the
        budget formulation and public investment planning processes in Mongolia, including the
        political preference for funding new investments over maintaining the existing capital
        stock, leading to the chronic underfunding of maintenance; the significant discretion of
        Parliament to add new projects to the public investment plan without any the need for a
        formal appraisal process, including a feasibility study; and the institutional weaknesses
        and poor procedures along the length of the project cycle.

    ·   Reforms in social protection are buttressed by the following studies, the 2009 World
        Bank Public Expenditure and Financial Management Review and "Assessment of the
        Child Money Program and properties of its targeting methodology," (Araujo, 2006).

    ·   Financial sector reforms can draw on the 2008 World Bank-IMF Financial Sector
        Assessment Report, and more recent World Bank reviews and assessments of the banking
        sector and recent developments (undertaken in 2008 and 2009).

    ·   In the mining sector, as a background study for this DPC, a mining revenue management
        options study, "Copper revenues and sustainable fiscal policy in Mongolia" (Budina, Van
        Wijnbergen and Li, 2009), was commissioned, which is currently under review.

    ·   In the area of governance, the DPC program is also informed by the governance
        challenges identified in the 2008 Governance Assessment Report associated with the
        mining taxation regime, the cadastre and licensing system, and the transparency of, and
        accountability for, mining revenues.




23Annex 3 links the prior actions in each of the policy areas directly to the relevant analytical work.


                                                     25

               VI.    THE PROPOSED LOAN: OPERATION DESCRIPTION


70.      The World Bank's proposed DPC is a single-tranche operation of US$40 million. While
it is acknowledged that, because of the magnitude of the shock, the adjustment effort will take
place over the next several years, the proposed instrument is a one-off single-tranche operation,
because of the many uncertainties and risks and the absence of a coherent and detailed medium-
term policy framework. This DPC is designed to assist the government in managing the
downturn, triggered by the collapse of the copper price, by supporting government efforts in the
policy areas most affected: (i) fiscal policy and management, given the budget's strong
dependence on mining revenues; (ii) social protection, given the impact of the economic
downturn on the poor; (iii) the financial sector, which was overheating when the global crisis hit,
and which experienced a major bank failure in late 2008; and (iv) the mining sector, given the
sector's importance in driving the recovery.

71.      A one-off operation, rather than a series, is judged to be a more appropriate instrument in
the current environment. The government is currently revising its medium-term plan, and seeking
to build consensus in Parliament. For that reason, defining specific prior actions for a DPC series
would be premature. However, the authorities have prepared an initial three-year policy matrix to
facilitate consensus-building around the reform agenda among the stakeholders. This framework
also provides an indication of the policy areas where the Bank and other development partners are
likely to engage with the government over the next few years. It is expected that a medium-term
reform agenda will be adopted later in the year.

72.      Although the policy actions to be supported by this operation are focused on managing
the downturn and urgently taking corrective action, this crisis also presents the government with
the opportunity to work towards putting in place a better medium-term framework going forward.
The necessity of agreeing to a set of binding rules to the budget approval process, which will help
Mongolia manage the boom and bust cycle of its mining revenues, may be felt more clearly now,
during the bust, than previously, during the boom. Re-introducing the targeting of social transfers
will not only save money, but will create a far more efficient poverty reduction program.
Similarly, addressing the current problems of the banking sector in a decisive and transparent way
can pave the way for a much stronger banking sector in the years to come. Finally, removing the
instability on mining policies sets the stage for increased, sustainable private sector investment to
lead the recovery.




                                                 26

                            Box 1. Good Practice Principles for Conditionality

Principle 1: Reinforce Ownership

The sudden onset of the economic crisis required the recently elected coalition government to make major
shifts in fiscal, monetary and exchange rate policies. This has not been easy, but the strong policy actions
taken in recent months demonstrate growing government ownership of the reform package needed.
Program design has benefited from systematic dialogue with key government officials and representatives
of both political parties, and has included consultations on individual policy reforms with the Prime
Minister and the Speaker of Parliament. In addition, a series of outreach and dissemination events of topical
analytical work and regular economic updates further helped raise awareness and ownership during
program design (Section V.B). However, risks remain, as indicated by the earlier experience with policy-
based lending (Section V.E). And a resurgence of the price of copper could undermine the current bi-
partisan commitment to reform (see the risk section, VIII.F).

Principle 2: Agree up front with the government and other financial partners on a coordinated
accountability framework

Government and the key development partners (viz. the IMF, the ADB, Japan and the World Bank) have
worked closely together in the design of the overall reform package. Joint work in several areas is being
undertaken, and a clear division of labor, which avoids overlapping or contradictory conditionality, has
been established. A special meeting to coordinate the support of the development partners was held, and a
joint policy matrix is currently being established by the government as the various support packages are
finalized.

Principle 3: Customize the accountability framework and modalities of Bank support to country
circumstances

The modalities and timing of the operation have been designed to support policy reforms in the key areas
most affected by the downturn and to meet the government's urgent need for financing of its budget gap.
The DPC will be processed under the IDA Financial Crisis Response Fast-Track Facility to accelerate the
disbursement. The short-term policy responses supported provide clear signals of the government's policy
directions for the medium term. However, a robust medium-term strategy still needs to be fully fleshed out.
Sensitive reforms such as the targeting of social transfers and the adoption of fiscal rules for the
management of mining revenues are in the process of being backed by analytical work done by the
development partners. This work will outline policy options for broader consultation.

Principle 4: Choose only actions critical for achieving results as conditions for disbursement

Only eight prior actions have been chosen in four key sectors. These actions were focused on achieving
concrete results for managing the downturn and laying the basis for an improved policy framework going
forward. All but two of the prior actions focus on implementation rather than action plans.

Principle 5: Conduct transparent progress reviews conducive to predictable and performance-based
financial support

It is a single-tranche DPC so there are only prior actions. The timing of the disbursement is in line with the
budget cycle in the sense that is helping to fill a financing gap. Preparation of a second DPC will start
immediately and will involve monitoring the evolving policy reform agenda and supporting the next set of
policy actions.




                                                     27

73.      The prior actions supported by the DPC are the following:

    ·    Fiscal policy and management

              o Capital budget planning and screening is improved, as demonstrated by the
                   exclusion of 30 projects without feasibility studies from the 2009 budget, as
                   amended in March.

              o Capital expenditures for the maintenance of basic infrastructure in the transport,
                   education and health sectors is protected, as evidenced by: (i) the increase in the
                   ratio of capital repairs to new investments from 2.5 percent (in the original
                   approved budget for 2009) to 3.4 percent (in the amended budget for 2009); and
                   (ii) the allocation of MNT 12.4 billion for that purpose.

    ·    Social protection

              o The Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor has prepared a time-bound action plan
                   to clean its roster of beneficiaries of the CMP, in order to reduce leakage to the
                   non-poor and improve its targeting on the poor.

    ·    Financial sector

              o The BoM has prepared an action plan for the restructuring/resolving of the bank
                   currently under the conservatorship, on the basis of the bank's portfolio
                   diagnostic and audit carried out by an internationally reputable auditor.

              o The BoM has issued a decree requiring that all banks report on a daily basis on
                   key indicators regarding their liquidity and asset quality.

              o The BoM has established a crisis management and systemic risk monitoring task
                   force with adequate functions and powers, qualified staff and sufficient resources
                   to carry out its mandate.

    ·    Mining

              o The Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy has developed and adopted
                   model investment agreements for the mining sector, clarifying Mongolia's
                   mining policy, including taxation and the state's capital participation, and
                   incorporating responsible mining practices consistent with the Equator
                   Principles.24

              o Sufficient resources have been transferred to the Mongolia EITI Secretariat in
                   order to finance an independent validation of its national EITI Program,
                   scheduled to be completed by March 31, 2010.




24The Equator Principles are the set of principles and financial industry benchmarks developed by private
financial institutions for determining assessing and managing social and environmental risks in project
financing. They were established in June 2003 and revised in July 2006, and modeled after the
environmental standards adopted by the World Bank and social policies promoted by the International
Financial Corporation.


                                                     28

     A. Fiscal Policy and Management

     a) Challenges

74.       The collapse of the mineral prices, in particular copper, resulted in a huge fiscal shock,
but also revealed a lack of proper management of mining revenues. Even though Mongolia did
save part of the mining windfall during the "boom" years, these were not enough to withstand a
commodity price shock of this magnitude. However, domestic policies also contributed. First,
during the "boom" years, the budget had become more and more dependent on the mining
revenues (see Table 2). Second, the non-mining deficit, i.e., expenditures relative to non-mining
revenues, rose dramatically, and, as has now become clear, unsustainably.

75.       The windfall was used mostly for capital expenditure, across the board wage increases
and untargeted social transfers. Capital expenditure more than tripled between 2006 and 2008 and
was not subject to feasibility studies whereas maintenance of existing infrastructure was
neglected (see next paragraphs). This provides the rationale why the 2009 budget amendment
focuses on canceling expenditure on projects without such feasibility studies. The additional
revenues were also used to make previously targeted social transfers universal, and to increase
wages and salaries (Figure 11).



 Figure 11. The windfall was used for poorly targeted spending and neglected maintenance
                                               of infrastructure

% of total expenditure                                                                      % of new investment




* Maintenance defined as Capital Repairs (in budget); probably underestimates actual capital repairs, as part is
included in other items. ** New investment defined as Domestic Investment only. *** budget.

Source: Ministry of Finance and World Bank




76.       Capital budget planning and execution is hindered as Parliament has a substantial role in
funding the public investment program. One important aspect of budget management in Mongolia
is that the budget proposal made by the Minister of Finance to Parliament can be amended in
many ways. As a result, overall fiscal targets can be overridden and key assumptions changed
(about mineral prices for instance). Additional capital projects can be included even in instances
in which these have not been subject to feasibility studies as required by the Public Sector and
Management of Finance Law (PSMFL). In this way, Parliamentary action increased the public


                                                        29

investment program budget by 52 percent in 2007 (1.9 percent of GDP) and by 21 percent in
2008 (1.6 percent of GDP), see Figure 12. More generally, the legal framework for budget
formulation, governed primarily by the PSMFL is silent on any limits on legislative changes.
Hence, the pro-cyclical pattern of fiscal policy was amplified by a powerful Parliament over-
riding the government's budget proposals.

                            Figure 12. Parliament has a substantial
                         influence over the public investment program

                         MNT billion




                         Note: This includes both the state budget and the
                              Mongolian Development Fund

                         Source: Ministry of Finance



77.      At the same time, insufficient resources were set aside for the proper maintenance of
existing infrastructure. Repairs and maintenance expenditures have not kept pace with the rapid
increases in capital expenditures -- declining from a ratio of 10.5 percent in 2004 to 5.8 percent
in 2008 -- compromising the sustainability of these projects and creating liabilities for the future
(Figure 11).

78.      However, the amended budget approved by Parliament in March 2009 demonstrates
Parliament's commitment to taking corrective action. First, it keeps the deficit to below 6 percent
of GDP deficit in 2009. If this amendment had not been made, the deficit would have spiraled to
over 12 percent of GDP. The size of the corrective action is a demonstration of the seriousness
and understanding of Parliament in dealing with this crisis. Second, the 2009 budget shows a
decreased dependence of mining-related revenues, partly as a result of increasing non-mining
revenues. The non-mining deficit is projected to narrow to 10.4 percent of GDP in 2009 from
15.3 percent of GDP in 2008. And third, Parliament has initiated a more prudent screening of
investment projects by postponing until the next budget all projects in the current for which no
feasibility studies had been conducted. Parliament also postponed all new projects for which
tenders have not been announced or construction contracts not finalized.

79.      These are steps in the right direction. The DPC's objective regarding ensuring fiscal
sustainability is to make sure that the current fiscal adjustments do not undermine future growth
prospects, but lay the basis for strengthening the capital budgeting process and improving fiscal
management in a mining-based economy.


                                                   30

    b) Key measures to be supported by the DPC

80.     The DPC will support government's efforts to maintain capital maintenance expenditures
in the budget for existing basic infrastructure (viz. roads, schools, hospitals) and the removal of
projects without feasibility studies. The budget for capital repairs (MNT 12.4 billion) will be
protected, and the ratio of capital repairs to new investments increased from 2.5 percent in the
original, approved budget to 3.4 percent in the amended budget for 2009. These actions set the
stage for increasing capital maintenance in the future and a better prioritization of capital
spending over the medium term. The DPC will assist the government to ensure that the necessary
fiscal adjustment reflected in the 2009 amended budget adheres to clear criteria for prioritizing
capital expenditures so as to minimize the impact on long-term growth. The reduction in capital
expenditures will be guided by the following principles: high priority projects will be maintained,
but all on-going projects that have entered implementation stage will be funded to ensure
completion, and all new projects without feasibility studies will be removed.

81.     For the medium term, it is necessary that during 2009 the economic classification of
maintenance is improved, so that all maintenance and repair expenditures are adequately recorded
and budgeted. The category of "capital repairs" in the budget underestimates total maintenance
expenditures as a fraction of the "Road Fund" and "domestic investment" categories is used for
maintenance and repairs. Based on this improved classification, the government can then set
targets for adequate maintenance expenditures as a share of new investment for the 2010 and
2011 budgets.

82.     Recognizing the urgent need for an agency at the center of government to manage and
coordinate the national planning system, the government has recently established the National
Development and Innovation Committee under the Prime Minister's office. The Committee's
mandate includes the preparation of a medium-term development plan, screening of the
investment projects of line ministries to ensure that they conform to national priorities, and
establishing arrangements for public-private partnerships in infrastructure. The Bank will provide
technical assistance to the Committee to help it realize these key objectives, including developing
and implementing robust criteria for project selection and appraisal to ensure that only those
projects enter the budget that fit into national strategic priorities and their operation and
maintenance is adequately funded.

83.     These measures will be complemented with continuous capacity building and technical
assistance. The Bank is providing on-going support in the Governance Assistance Project (GAP)
and the Economic Capacity and Technical Assistance Project (ECTAC). The ECTAC project
funds are being reallocated to be better synchronized with the DPC actions, and with the
requirements imposed by the economic crisis. The Bank has been effectively coordinating
technical assistance with the Fiscal Affairs Department of the IMF and looks forward to a
continued partnership.

84.     Government is planning to improve fiscal management going forward by setting binding
expenditure limits for government and Parliament. In Mongolia, the PSFML requires a medium-
term fiscal framework (MTFF) to be in place, but is largely silent on its content, the institutional
responsibilities for its development, and does not require Parliament to approve budgets that
conform to its fiscal targets. The law requires the submission to Parliament, by May 1, of a Fiscal
Framework Statement (FFS) that contains the MTFF outlining the government's medium term
objectives and fiscal targets. The MoF, specifically the Economic Policy Department and the
Fiscal Policy and Coordination Department, are responsible for the preparation of the MTFF. The
current MTFF targets a deficit of 3 percentage of GDP, which has resulted in a pro-cyclical fiscal
policy. The government is committed to adopt a more appropriate fiscal rule to anchor the FFS.


                                                 31

85.      Where fiscal rules have been used to govern budgetary use of volatile natural resource
income in other countries, they have essentially been of three types: (a) the permanent income
rule (PI), whereby transfers from the resource fund are set at their "permanent income
equivalent", i.e., at a level that can be maintained forever given expectations about future
extraction and prices; (b) the bird-in-the-hand rule (Norway), whereby expenditure from the fund
is restricted to its (real) interest income; and (c) the reference price rule, whereby transfers are set
at the revenue level that would have accrued if a particular reference price would have prevailed.
Considerable care needs to be taken to adopt the appropriate fiscal rule tailored to Mongolia's
circumstances and the Fiscal Responsibility Law (FRL) should be based on a discussion of
different options that are thoroughly debated in Parliament.

86.      The Ministry of Finance, with technical assistance from the IMF and the World Bank, is
drafting a new FRL that would institutionalize such a fiscal rule. The World Bank is currently
undertaking analytical work to assist with the formulation of these options. The draft law will
anchor fiscal policy in an appropriate fiscal rule that reduces the impact of the volatility of
mineral prices on the budget, and requires that the MTFF, budgets, and budget amendments be
within the constraints of the fiscal rule limits. Submission to Parliament of the FRL by December
31, 2009 is a Structural Benchmark of the IMF program.

87.      As part of the emerging medium-term agenda, the government intends to make
complementary amendments to some of the provisions in the existing Law on Parliamentary
Procedures that govern the budget discussions in Parliament to complement the FRL and to avoid
any potential loopholes regarding the restrictions imposed in Parliament in the FRL.

88.      As mentioned, Mongolia's legal framework gives unusual powers to the Parliament to
engage in budget planning. Parliament has the authority to amend the budget without regard to
the fiscal targets set in the MTFF, such as increasing total appropriations. The PSMFL gives
inadequate attention to capital budgeting, does not enforce a comprehensive budget, especially
with regards to the treatment of extra-budgetary funds and quasi-government entities, and
provides little guidance to structuring medium-term fiscal and budgetary processes.25 Some
features of the legal framework, in particular the provisions for performance management and full
accrual accounting, may also not be suitable for Mongolia at its current stage of institutional
development.

89.      The submission of a draft new Integrated Budget Law (IBL) to Parliament is a key
element of the government's medium-term reform program. With technical assistance from the
IMF and the World Bank, the government is preparing the draft new IBL for submission to
Parliament in the fall 2009 session. The draft law will address the identified pitfalls of the current
legal framework as described above.

90.      While improvements in the legal framework and in capital budgeting are the top priorities
for the government, it is also important to sustain the momentum in second-generation reforms to
introduce medium-term program budgeting. With technical assistance from the ECTAC project,
the Ministry of Finance has been making gradual but steady progress in this area and in 2009, and
following a government resolution of June 2008, portfolio ministries for the first time submitted
program-based budgets for 2009-11. These budgets at present are only documents and
considerable work is required to modify institutional processes to make them operational. Both
the IMF and the World Bank are providing technical assistance for the preparation and
implementation of an implementation action plan for the phased introduction of medium term
program budgeting.


25IMF (2008).


                                                   32

91.     DPC prior actions

    ·   Capital budget planning and screening is improved, as demonstrated by the exclusion of
        30 projects without feasibility studies from the 2009 budget, as amended in March.
    ·   Capital expenditures for the maintenance of basic infrastructure in the transport,
        education and health sectors is protected, as evidenced by: (i) the increase in the ratio of
        capital repairs to new investments from 2.5 percent (in the original approved budget for
        2009) to 3.4 percent (in the amended budget for 2009); and (ii) the allocation of MNT
        12.4 billion for that purpose.

    c) Expected results

92.     The emerging medium-term strategy would build on the above short-term measures as
follows. As part of IMF conditionality, a draft Fiscal Responsibility Law would be submitted to
Parliament by the end of 2009. This Law would include a framework for better managing of the
mining revenues. A new IBL would then follow, and lay out more rigorous procedures for project
selection and appraisal, including improved cost estimation and sustainable funding for
maintenance and repair. The expected results would be a more sustainable fiscal framework to
manage the volatile mining revenues and a better planned and executed public investment
program.


    B. Social Protection

    a) Challenges

93.     In its transition to a market economy, Mongolia adopted a social assistance system to
address the needs of people who lost their traditional safety net--jobs and pensions--and were
not covered by social insurance. The public safety net system included two main types of
programs: social insurance (retirement, unemployment, or sickness); social assistance (specific
benefits to protect vulnerable groups, including the disabled and child allowances). And there are
active labor market programs (ALMPs): job mediation services, entrepreneurship services, job
training, public works and wage subsidies. Social insurance is only available to workers
contributing to the social security system (40 percent of workers in 2006)26. Up until the 2006
amendments to the Labor Law, ALMPs have been limited to the unemployed who are registered
at the Labor and Social Welfare Assistance Divisions (54 percent of the total unemployed, or
about 30,000 people)27. The main legal framework for social assistance benefits was provided by
the 1995 Social Welfare Law and the 2001 Employment Promotion Law.

94.     The 2003 Social Security Sector Master Plan (SSMP) had the right ideas but no clear
implementation strategy for consolidating and rationalizing the system to achieve a coherent
social assistance strategy. The SSMP aimed to consolidate and rationalize the system and
improve cost-efficiency (mainly through improved targeting). In particular, the main areas of
reform of social assistance identified in the master plan were: (a) to rationalize the number and
type of benefits; (b) to clarify the eligibility criteria of the different benefits to improve quality
and accessibility of the sector's services; (c) to decentralize the management of social assistance
services; (d) to professionalize the social welfare officers in charge of implementing social
assistance; and (e) to promote community participation in specific care-provider institutions.



262006 Household Income and Expenditure Survey.
272002-2003 Living Standards Measurement Survey.



                                                  33

95.     The introduction of the Child Money Program (CMP) in January 2005 responded in part
to the strategy laid out in the SSMP, in particular the need to consolidate programs and improve
targeting. The CMP was originally designed as a conditional cash transfer program (CCT)
targeted to poor households with children aged 0-18. It introduced two important innovations in
the social assistance system: it conditioned the benefit receipt to specific behaviors on the part of
the households; and it introduced a proxy-means test (PMT) for the identification of the poor.
Cash transfers were conditioned on following mandatory immunizations, living with parents, not
being engaged in intolerable forms of child labor and, for children between the ages of 8 and 18,
being enrolled in school.

96.     The 2005 targeted CMP introduced the principle of beneficiaries being selected on the
basis of need through an objective set of indicators, replacing the old system of subjective
assessment of poverty by local authorities. Although the objectives were not clearly spelled out,
the basic design of the CMP mimics that of successful CCTs elsewhere, which have the dual goal
of reducing current poverty (by providing monetary transfers to poor families) and reducing
future poverty through improved human capital (by conditioning benefits on human capital
investments).

97.     However, the amendments to the Social Welfare Law of July 2006 universalized the
CMP and introduced other large allowances--all facilitated by large revenues from mining. The
CMP was universalized to all families with children in July 2006 and the benefit was increased in
January 2007 from MNT 36,000 per child a year (MNT 3,000 per month) to MNT 136,000. The
CMP was largely moved out of the budget into the newly established Mongolian Development
Fund (MDF), with the objective of managing the fiscal revenue from the Windfall Profits Tax on
copper and gold production. Also, two large one-off allowances were introduced--MNT 500,000
for newlyweds and MNT 100,000 for new-born children. The July 2006 amendments also
consolidated all other child-related allowances (other than the CMP) into a single CCT of MNT
20,000 per month.

98.     Social assistance expenditures have been increasing continuously since 1997, but they
skyrocketed after introduction of the CMP in 2005 and the subsequent changes, resulting in large
increases in the share of social assistance in the total budget and GDP. Between 1997 and 2004,
social assistance increased by 127 percent in real terms. The introduction of the CMP in 2005
increased expenditures by 61 percent, and further increased by 54 percent with universalization of
CMP in 2006. The January 2007 benefit raise has increased projected expenditures by 173
percent. Over that period, the share of social assistance in the budget and GDP went from 2.2
percent and 0.7 percent in 1997, respectively, to a projected 11.9 percent and 5.2 percent in 2007,
respectively.

99.     Soon after its introduction in January 2005, the CMP quickly became the largest social
assistance program, accounting for 67 percent of beneficiaries and 40 percent of the budget in
2005. By April-June of 2006 (right before the universalization of the program), 68 percent of
families with children were benefiting from the program, which covered 29 percent of all children
aged 0-18 in the country. In fact, in 2006 the CMP represented the main source of welfare
payments to households together with the traditional main source of welfare payments (pensions).
It accounted for 44 percent of welfare payments to an average household--62 percent among
households receiving CMP benefit--and 8 percent of their income.

100.    Several recent empirical studies present evidence on the efficiency of the targeted CMP,
as well as of the impacts on poverty and child schooling of both the targeted and universal




                                                 34

versions of the CMP.28 The evidence shows considerable leakage of targeted CMP program
benefits to the non-poor while it excluded a portion of the poor. The technical dimensions of the
CMP targeting formula had a lot of room for improvement but, more importantly, it was poorly
applied. This resulted in large leakage of the program to the non-poor. Using the population-
weighted average of the Minimum Subsistence Level (MSL) in 2006 (MNT 25,620) as the
national poverty line, 19 percent of the poor were excluded from the program and 61 percent of
the non-poor were included. Disaggregating by quintile of household per capita consumption
(Figure 13), 19 percent of the households in the poorest two quintiles were excluded from the
program, while 55 percent of those in the richest two quintiles received benefits. And the poorest
two quintiles only account for 50 percent of total beneficiary households. So a lot of benefits
went to household that did not need them, resulting in large cost-inefficiencies. This was a result
both of the technical properties of the targeting formula that was applied and, more importantly,
of its poor implementation.

                Figure 13. A large leakage of the Child Money Program benefits
                                       to non-poor households

                   %




               Source: World Bank (2009b)



101.    Nonetheless, the targeted CMP was found to have a positive impact on high-school
enrollment in Mongolia ­ specifically among the poor. After controlling for differences between
CMP beneficiaries and non-beneficiaries, the program is associated with a 16 percentage point
increase in the probability of being enrolled in upper secondary school among 16-18 year olds
who have completed lower secondary. Analysis by quintile of household per capita consumption
shows a large and statistically significant effect among the poor ­ 35 percentage points among
those in the poorest quintile ­ but no significant effect among the non-poor (e.g., the richest two
quintiles), see Figure 14.




28World Bank (2009b).


                                                35

                          Figure 14. Child Money Program has a large
                            impact on high school enrollment among
                              the poor but no effect on the non-poor

                        Percentage point difference in enrollment by quintile




                      Source: World Bank (2009b)



102.    The targeted CMP--with a smaller monetary transfer to households--had a significant,
but relatively small, impact on poverty. The analysis of household per capita consumption with
and without CMP income shows that the program appears to be associated with small changes in
poverty--a 4 percent reduction in the overall poverty rate and a 1.6 percent reduction in extreme
poverty.29 Note that the benefit of the program was only one-eighth of the poverty line in 2002-
03. After the CMP was universalized, the size of the benefit was also substantially increased.

103.    The universalized CMP­which also involved a huge increase in the size of the benefit
(from 36,000 to 136,000 MNT per child per year)­was found to have a larger impact on poverty
than the earlier targeted CMP. The comparison of simulated household consumption expenditures
with universal CMP benefits at MNT 136,000 a year per child and expenditures without CMP
income show a 15 percentage point reduction in the overall poverty rate and a 5 percentage point
reduction in extreme poverty.

104.    While the universal CMP benefit appears to have a larger impact on poverty than the
targeted CMP benefit, it does so at a much higher fiscal cost. Moreover, the universal CMP is
much more cost inefficient than the targeted version. There is no evidence to date on how much
additional benefit the universal CMP transfer provides the poor in terms of school enrollments.
There is the potential risk the higher universal CMP transfer may create disincentives to work
among the poor,30 given the large size of the transfer relative to household consumption among
the poor (30 percent among the poorest quintile). Moreover, it is clear that the fiscal burden and
cost inefficiency from granting benefits to all non-poor households is far higher under the
universal program than under the targeted version, which makes the universal program fiscally
unsustainable.




29UNICEF (2007).
30World Bank (2009b).


                                                     36

    b) Key measures to be supported by the DPC

          i) Reintroducing targeting of the CMP

105.     There are clear gains--in terms of efficiency and fiscal sustainability of the safety net--
to moving to a targeted version of the CMP. The important social benefits of the CMP--increased
school enrollment, poverty reduction--are concentrated among the poor and extreme poor.
Untargeted, universal benefits only add to the fiscal burden of the program, while serving as a
consumption subsidy to the non-poor.

106.     The DPC and potential future DPCs will thus support re-targeting of the CMP program to
focus scarce government resources where they can have an impact: on poverty reduction and
human capital promotion. To promote fiscal sustainability of the program in the short term, the
DPC will support a process of conversion of the current universal program to a targeted program
based on a proxy-means targeting formula developed using the most recent household survey data
(2007/08). The implementation of this formula would avoid the problems that were encountered
in 2005 and that were to a large extent the cause of the poor performance of the prior targeting
experience. In transitioning to the targeted CMP and in order to respond to the urgency of the
current fiscal crisis, the CMP would begin by cleaning its roster and eliminating households that
are clearly non-poor (e.g. formal sector workers, civil servants, and others). A plan to carry out
this revision of the roster would constitute a prior action under the DPC.

107.     Following a rapid reduction in the size of the universal CMP through a cleaning of the
rosters, a second DPC, supported by a new TA program for social protection, would support the
government in progressively improving the implementation of the updated program targeting to
achieve a program that is focused on a more narrow definition of the poor, based on an updated
targeting formula using the national poverty line. The movement to more narrow poverty
targeting of the program would be undertaken in a phased way over a multi-year period, to enable
the development of the technical and institutional mechanisms required to effectively implement
a mechanism to target the poor. It is proposed that potential future DPCs support this transition.
Progress in the implementation of the new targeting formula would constitute prior actions for
potential further DPCs.

          ii) Reducing number of social transfers

108.     Potential future DPCs, supported by a TA program, would also support the government
in improving the efficiency and fiscal sustainability of the country's system of social transfers
through the consolidation and rationalization of its system of social transfers. Recent analysis of
social protection in Mongolia31 noted that the country's safety net programs would benefit from
consolidation of its multiplicity of programs, for reasons related to efficiency and sustainability as
well as rationality and impact of the system.

          iii)Adjusting the size of the social transfer

109.     The DPC will also support the adjustment of the size of the targeted CMP transfer in a
way that ensures both fiscal responsibility and adequacy in terms of impact on the poor. At
present the CMP comprises a monthly payment (MNT 3,000 per child per month or MNT 36,000
per child per year), and a quarterly payment (MNT 25,000 per child per month or MNT 100,000
per child per year). Newlyweds receive a one-time payment (MNT 300,000)32, and households
receive a one-time payment per new-born child (MNT 100,000). As part of the rationalization of


31World Bank (2009b).
32Before the March 2009 budget amendment this was a MNT 500,000 payment.


                                                   37

social transfers, potential future DPCs would support the revision of the monetary amount of
these transfers, consistent with the objectives of the programs (investment in children's education,
poverty reduction, and others). The technical assistance being provided as part of the DPC as well
as ongoing analytical work on poverty will inform this reform.

         iv) Strengthening the government's capacity to implement effective targeted transfers

110.    To successfully move from a universal social transfer to a well-targeted, modern safety
net program, Mongolia will require technical assistance both at the central and local government
levels. A recent World Bank study of social protection in Mongolia33 highlights several key areas
where institutional strengthening is needed, including:

    ·   Improving the PMT for progressively better poverty targeting.
    ·   Training/technical assistance to relevant Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor and local
        government staff to ensure adequate execution of the targeted CMP program.
    ·   Development of a national beneficiary database to ensure clear and transparent
        monitoring of program eligibility and payments.
    ·   Establishment of a complaint mechanism to address a range of household concerns about
        the program.
    ·   Establishment of a direct-deposit mechanism for CMP program payment, along the lines
        of the mechanism currently used for pensions.
    ·   Implementation of an impact evaluation program for the targeted CMP to ensure the
        program is meeting its objectives and to permit adjustments to program design and
        implementation to enhance the CMP's impact on poverty and human capital promotion
        among the poor.

111.    These measures are part of the implementation of the reformed CMP. They will be part of
possible future DPCs and a planned social protection TA program.

112.    DPC prior actions

    ·   The Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor has prepared a time-bound action plan to clean
        its roster of beneficiaries of the CMP, in order to reduce leakage to the non-poor and
        improve its targeting on the poor.

    c) Expected results

113.    The emerging medium-term strategy would build on the above short-term measures as
follows. The medium­term goal of the envisaged reforms with respect to social transfers is to
better protect the poor by targeting the currently untargeted grants (in particular, the CMP).
During 2009, the government will propose to Parliament legislation which will consolidate
several existing social transfer programs into one social protection program and reintroduce
targeting. Work will also start on establishing an improved PMT and a national beneficiary
database. Subsequently, a strategy for monitoring and evaluating of the reformed social transfer
program will be put in place, and a complaint mechanism for the consolidated program
established. Later on, a monitoring and evaluation program for the consolidated social transfer
program and a direct-deposit mechanism for the consolidated social transfer program will be
needed. The goal will be to gradually implement the PMT-based targeting, so that by December
2010, the national beneficiary database has been completed at the national level.



33World Bank (2009b).


                                                 38

     C. Financial Sector

     a) Challenges

114.     The government faces the challenge of dealing with the resolution of the recently failed
fourth largest bank and preparing for further possible bank failures due to the downturn. To
restore confidence in the system, the government introduced a four-year deposit guarantee34 and
took the failed bank under conservatorship. However, significant system weaknesses and
important risks remain. For instance, there is limited financial system oversight capacity. And
most financial institutions have inadequate risk management capacity, weak corporate
governance and internal control mechanisms. Weak liquidity management and the absence of
depositor insurance also limit the ability of the system to absorb shocks without government
support. Consequently, as the economy slows down, some of the other weaker banks may also
fail. Non-performing loans (NPLs), which had been below 3 percent for the banking system until
the mid-2008, more than doubled by early 2009.

     b) Key measures to be supported by the DPC

115.     Immediate response and contingency measures are needed to address bank failures,
restore confidence in the banking system and strengthen banking supervision.

116.     The government recognizes that the immediate task at hand comprises conducting a
special portfolio diagnostic and audit of the failed bank to determine the extent and nature of both
the problem and the viable assets held. To this end the BoM has already hired an auditing firm of
international standard which is in the process of finalizing its assessment. The government
intends to use the result of this special audit mentioned above to serve as the basis for the design
of a strategy and procedures for an expedient least-cost resolution of the bank promptly. The
authorities recognize that in the prevailing global market situation any additional bank failure
beyond the failed bank, however small or insignificant one, will be viewed as a test to the
capacity of the authorities to handle the situation. To that extent, successful resolution of the
failed bank would allow the authorities to demonstrate their commitment and capability to the
general public, and thus serve to calm the markets.

117.     Given the seriousness of the economic downturn, the strain it causes on the banking
system, and the inherent weaknesses in the banking system, the BoM has enhanced its day-to-day
monitoring of the banks, as well as prepared a contingency plan which encompasses a range of
scenarios. The focus of the enhanced oversight will be on the presently most pertinent challenges,
namely: (i) liquidity situation; (ii) asset quality; and (iii) the impact of foreign currency
fluctuations on the aforementioned. The enhanced monitoring of the banks' liquidity position and
prospects is both timely and forward-looking. To that extent, besides the measures already in
use,35 the supervisor also intends to put in place an enhanced liquidity-monitoring regime, both
for domestic and important foreign currencies, that entails routine stress testing placed on cash
flow projections. The banks will then be requested to prepare and submit to the supervisor on
daily basis detailed rolling cash flow projections, at minimum, for the next five working days.




34The government has subsequently clarified the deposit guarantee to cover current accounts, savings
accounts, time deposits and interbank deposits. However, in order to prevent abuse and unnecessary fiscal
costs, deposits of related persons--as defined in the banking law--and deposits of holders of subordinated
debts will be excluded from this guarantee.

35BoM has recently instituted a requirement that each bank report its deposit levels on a daily basis.


                                                    39

118.      Further actions to which the authorities are committed include also monitoring large
deposit concentrations and prompt reporting by banks of any pending expiries of large deposit
concentrations or significant deposit withdrawals. The BoM intends to closely follow deposit
rates offered by the banks, as excessive rates tend to signal possible liquidity problems. Given
also that some Mongolian banks report relatively sizable "due from banks" assets, the authorities
will seek to reassure themselves on the quality and liquidity of such placements with foreign
banks.

119.      Similarly, an enhanced monitoring regime of the asset quality will be put in place,
particularly for both systemically important, and potentially weak and problem banks. This will
entail augmented monitoring of the banks' compliance with loan classification and provisioning
requirements. For early detection of potentially weak banks, the authorities will seek to identify
the techniques most commonly used by banks to hide the problems through use of "cosmetic"
restructurings with insolvent debtors, and evaluate the extent to which such techniques are
applied by each bank. Furthermore, to the extent possible under the presently available
supervisory powers,36 the authorities will pay close attention to the banks' compliance with
single-borrower restrictions and connected-party lending.

120.      The foreign currency risk exposure inherent from unhedged currency loans will be
monitored and regularly assessed using stress-testing techniques. This is due to the relatively high
level of dollarization in the economy, and the concerns over tugrug weakness. Both banks and
authorities will benefit from early consideration on how to convert existing unhedged dollar
exposures to tugrug-denominated loans.

121.      The BoM is also paying close attention to the quality of off-balance sheet transactions
and contingent liabilities. In autumn 2008 the Mongolian banking system was plagued by
reported and/or rumored problems with Letters of Credit at different banks. To that extent, and
given that some of the banks allegedly engage in commodity derivatives trading, the quality of
off-balance sheet transactions and contingent liabilities deserved attention. Another undertaking
was to clarify the precise coverage of the blanket deposit guarantee, at minimum excluding the
related parties (shareholders, ultimate beneficial owners and related companies). In this regard,
Parliament recently approved an amendment to this guarantee to Parliament which clarifies the
scope of the guarantee and excludes certain types of depositors, such as connected parties, as
requested by the IMF.

122.      The BoM recognizes that the number of staff will need to be increased and the
supervisory staff will need to be reorganized to accommodate for the specific needs of resolution
and contingency planning processes while maintaining robust bank supervision of particularly
systemically important and potentially weak and problem banks. The true quality of banks'
liquidity position and asset quality can only be observed through frequent onsite supervision.
However, BoM bank supervisory staff are already stretched extremely thin, having to deal with
both the conservatorship of the failed bank and planning for its resolution as well as developing a
contingency planning framework for possible further banking sector disturbance, alongside their
regular duties. These three undertakings--failed-bank resolution, contingency planning, and
routine bank supervision--each represent very different and challenging tasks, with sometimes
conflicting demands on the staff, the management and their time. To that extent, to remove these
binding constraints and inherent conflicts, there is an urgent need not only to increase the number
of staff, but also to reorganize the supervisory staff to accommodate for the specific needs of


36Absent full transparency of the ownership structure of the banks, effective supervision for compliance
with a number of prudential regulations, including restrictions on related party lending and large exposures
is, at best, challenging.


                                                    40

resolution and contingency planning processes while maintaining robust bank supervision of
particularly systemically important and potentially weak and problem banks.

123.    The BoM is in the process of establishing a separate, adequately resourced crisis
management task force/designate body with requisite legal/regulatory powers and direct
communication lines to BoM top management, the Financial Stability Council (FSC),37 and other
relevant agencies. The efficacy of the enhanced supervision effort as well as possible crisis
management tasks would greatly be aided through added focus and specialization. Expedience
becomes of essence, both in early detection of any problems, in communication between relevant
authorities, and in response design and decisions. The crisis management task force should be
tasked with dealing with efforts related to immediate banking sector distress, such as (i)
functioning as the focal point on the government side to ensure a seamless information flow
between key authorities (including the day-to-day and enhanced bank supervision); (ii)
conducting the ongoing planning and oversight for failed-bank resolution processes (for example,
the conservator of the failed bank); (iii) doing the preparatory work for requisite policy decisions
by the FSC, BoM and other relevant authorities; and (iv) proactively monitoring and regularly
reporting systemic risk concerns and issues to BoM senior management and the FSC as needed.
Concurrently, the Central Bank Law would need to be amended to strengthen BoM independence
and to provide appropriate legal protection for BoM, the crisis management task force and
individual supervisors for actions taken in good faith in the course of performing supervisory
duties.

124.    Given that Mongolia underwent a systemic banking crisis only relatively recently, the
authorities want to early-on revisit the actions taken and the lessons learned from the late-1990s
crisis. Based on these lessons, as well as drawing from the international experiences from
comparable situations, the authorities will then seek to review of the existing bank resolution
framework to ensure that it is sufficiently robust and provides for effective and efficient bank
resolution process in a systemic distress situation. To that extent, at minimum, the Banking Law,
Central Bank Law, Corporate Law and Civil Code will be reviewed for what amendments may be
needed to provide the BoM--and thus also the crisis management task force--with adequate
powers and flexibility for use of a wide range of bank resolution techniques. Appropriate
amendments to the laws on foreclosure and collateral will also be considered and presented to the
Parliament to ensure that borrowers are not overly protected impeding loan recovery. In parallel,
the tax rules will also be assessed against different resolution techniques, including mergers and
acquisitions, to facilitate prompt action, and allow asset transfers and other transactions in a bank
resolution, without distorting or offsetting the corrective nature of such measures. Further, a
review and amendments, as needed, of the foreclosure legislation and procedures will be
beneficial to the pertinent needs of the present situation.

125.    One key task for the crisis management task force would be to develop an overall
contingency planning framework, and to draft a contingency plan of action for different
scenarios, ranging from payment system disturbance, the collapse of a small, relatively
unimportant bank, to a possible collapse of one or even several large systemically important
banks. To avoid unnecessary confusion and inconsistent ad hoc responses, the contingency plan
will spell out clearly, to begin with, the decision-making procedures and powers related to dealing
with systemic banking sector distress:



37The Financial Stability Council (FCS) is a body comprising the BoM, the MoF and the Financial
Regulatory Commission (FRC) and is responsible for financial-sector-related policy issues, and
coordination and cooperation between these three agencies, see also
http://www.mongolbank.mn/c/journal_articles/view_article_content?articleId=A-COUNCIL&version=1.0.



                                                  41

    ·    What are the requisite measures for early detection of any problems (as discussed
         above)?

    ·    At what point does a bank move from normal supervisory oversight to more intensive
         day-to-day supervision?

    ·    Who has the authority to determine that intervention is needed in a weak, or potentially
         failed, bank and on what basis?

    ·    What are the arrangements for:

         o conducting an in-depth assessment of a failing bank's condition, including the use of
              independent experts if necessary;
         o reporting the assessment's findings to the relevant authorities for decision-making?

    ·    What are the appropriate and effective bank resolution techniques in the Mongolian
         context?

    ·    What are the responsibilities for deciding on the requisite intervention actions, such as:

         o taking physical control of the banking facilities, and transferring or repaying
              deposits;
         o interagency communication and coordination of resolution actions;
         o communicating to other relevant parties, including the general public;
         o determining potential conflicts with the objectives of government or other relevant
              agencies, and how these might be resolved; and
         o monitoring the results from intervention, and adjusting the actions as necessary?

126.     The authorities recognize that the shock and the consequent slowdown in economic
activity provide an opportunity to consolidate the banking system to strengthen it. Should
intervention in a number of banks be needed, meaning any additional banks beyond the failed
bank, the credibility of the authorities' actions can only be maintained, if there is a clear,
consistent, and principled strategy in place, and no ad hoc and inconsistent decisions are made.
Any use of public support requires certain safeguard provisions to be in place, such as making
certain that the support is conditional on proper repercussions, and that the tax payers share in the
upside from the intervention. Authorities therefore recognize that any bank receiving public
support should meet the following preconditions:

    ·    fully transparent ownership structure;

    ·    fit and proper owners and managers;

    ·    willingness of the owners to put a sufficient amount of their own capital at risk;

    ·    recognition of the full extent of losses and appropriate loan-loss provisioning;

    ·    commitment to requisite operational restructuring to ascertain the future feasibility of the
         bank; and

    ·    a realistic business plan to return the bank to full viability, including meeting all
         prudential requirements.




                                                  42

127.    DPC prior actions

    ·   The BoM has prepared an action plan for the restructuring/resolving of the bank currently
        under the conservatorship, on the basis of the bank's portfolio diagnostic and audit
        carried out by an internationally reputable auditor.

    ·   The BoM has issued a decree requiring that all banks report on a daily basis on key
        indicators regarding their liquidity and asset quality.

    ·   The BoM has established a crisis management and systemic risk monitoring task force
        with adequate functions and powers, qualified staff and sufficient resources to carry out
        its mandate.

    c) Expected results

128.    The emerging medium-term strategy would build on the above short-term measures by
continuing to strengthen bank supervision, while swiftly and resolutely dealing with possible
future bank failures. The government is expected to mandate a well-sequenced increase of paid-in
capital over the next few years to provide incentives for bank restructuring in the sector. The idea
would be that mainly the stronger banks would be able to attract the necessary capital. The
expected results would be a better supervised banking sector without any more failures of major,
systemic banks. The sector would be characterized by more stable and balanced growth in
deposits and loans.


    D. Mining Sector Reform

    a) Challenges

129.    Mongolia has bright prospects for both fuel and non-fuel minerals and the mining sector
has the potential to be the main driver of economic growth over the medium to long term. This
potential will only be fully realized in an environment, where both the regulatory framework and
the institutions that manage that framework are effective and efficient. Mineral revenues from
taxes, royalties and dividends rose dramatically through the 2005-08 commodity price boom,
accounting for 39 percent of government revenue in 2007, and reaching 62 percent of total
exports.

130.    Since 2006, however, the mineral sector has been characterized by uncertainties. These
uncertainties stem from both the law itself, as well as the arbitrary and less-than-transparent
application of existing regulations. Investors perceive there is a lack of transparency and
accountability of government actions, but there is also poor monitoring and accountability on the
part of the private-sector operators. In particular, the management of mineral licensing has
repeatedly been raised by the mining industry as a disincentive to mineral exploration and has led
to allegations of corrupt practice in license allocation. Licenses are currently processed following
a series of internal instructions which can be changed at will by the Ministry of Mineral
Resources and Energy, potentially placing companies in breach of conditions that did not exist on
the grant of their license. Lack of adequate regulations passed by either Cabinet or Parliament that
define due process and provide certainly and accountability for both investor and the government
is undermining investor confidence.

131.    Mining sector uncertainty has been compounded by increasing economic nationalism
with Parliament passing legislation requiring state equity participation in all major mining
projects. The Minerals Law was amended in 2006 to require a 34 percent state equity holding in



                                                  43

all projects discovered with private sector exploration and a 50 percent share in projects originally
discovered using state funded exploration (during the socialist era). The government is not in a
position to fund this equity and is seeking arrangements where the stake is funded and carried by
the developer and paid for out of future dividends. This adds to investor risk and creates
uncertainty over the level of equity which the state may claim. Definitions in the law are vague
and "discovered with State Funds" is otherwise undefined. Revision and clarification of the
Minerals Law to provide for regulations and improvement of terms and definitions is required.

132.     Coupled with the disincentive effects of this weak regulatory setting has been instability
in the fiscal framework and the application of a discriminatory Windfall Profits Tax (WPT) on
gold and copper producers. This tax has distorted both exploration and development expenditures
and resulted in the deferral of new gold mines and was a contributor to the delay in completing an
investment agreement for OT.        38The WPT has been levied using arbitrary commodity price
thresholds which for a time were inconsistent with the concept of a windfall and were in fact set
at levels below the operating costs of some mines. Thus all profits from copper and gold mining
were being taxed at a rate of 68 percent.

133.     Mining sector tax legislation is poorly defined. The Income Tax Law has no specific
division or sections dealing with mining taxation and the sector is treated the same as any other
industrial operation. This results in significant areas of ambiguity and results in frequent court
challenges by mining companies to tax assessments by the General Department of National
Taxation. The mining sector has many aspects including depreciation arrangements, treatment of
social, infrastructure, environmental and rehabilitation costs which are unique to the sector.
Development and enactment of a division in the Income Tax Act dealing with mining sector
related issues is urgently required.

134.     Investment agreements are provided for in the Minerals Law to provide stability and
certainty for mining developments, such as stabilization of fiscal terms, and to define issues such
as the arrangements for the acquisition by the state of any equity position. These agreements are
currently developed by the state responding to draft agreements proposed by the investors and, as
a result, place the state in a position of reacting to proposals rather than setting the agenda for the
agreement. The state urgently needs a draft model investment agreement that spells out the basic
terms of any investment agreement and forms the basis of negotiations with the private sector.
Completion of such an agreement will require the state to clarify and solidify its policy position
on many aspects related to mining project development.

135.     Mongolia has a large informal mining sector characterized by illegal artisanal and small-
scale mining by individuals and groups, also called "ninja miners".39 It is estimated that there are
currently in the order of 60,000 such miners extracting a range of commodities from gold to coal
and fluorspar with and annual value estimated at US$140 million. A significant number illegally
use mercury, cyanide and explosives under often hazardous conditions. Education and
development of the sector has been impossible due to the absence of appropriate legislation and
the fact that the activity is illegal. The inability to formalize and regularize the sector has
perpetuated environmental damage and leaves a significant sector outside the formal and taxable
economy. The government recently passed a temporary regulation as a first step towards


38The Oyu Tolgoi deal has now been submitted to Parliament in March 2009 and has been discussed
during the Parliament's Spring Session.

39The miners are so named because the green bowls they use for panning, when carried on their backs, are
said to resemble the shells of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, a popular early-1990s TV series featuring
four mutant ninja-practising turtles who live in the New York sewage system while fighting crime and who
are named after famous Italian renaissance artists.


                                                     44

formalization of the sector and this needs to be followed by the passage of a Small-Scale Mining
Law.

136.    Mongolia has an urgent need for appropriate trade skills development and advanced
technical and vocational education. Mongolia does not yet have a workforce that is well trained in
modern technical skills. This skills shortage is evident even in quite basic-level jobs in
construction where many non-Mongolian workers are currently engaged. Unless there is a
concerted effort to improve technical and vocational education and training, it is likely that
foreign workers will dominate the construction and operations of the major mining projects, and
the process of converting the work force to Mongolian citizens will prove to be challenging.
Expatriate workers are expected to dominate the senior levels of mining operations management
until such time as a cadre of Mongolians develops the technical and management skills required
to replace them. The larger mining companies have recognized this skills shortage dilemma and
are already providing scholarships for advanced engineering and geological studies, and some are
proposing to build staff training centers at their mines. With respect to trade training, there
remains an urgent need to expand the scope and quality of apprenticeship training for basic trade
skills to an international standard. Technical vocational skills (certificate and diploma level
technical skills) for fields such as heavy equipment maintenance, welding, and construction
management are also required. The quality of engineering and geology degree programs currently
offered in Mongolia requires improvement to meet international standards, and high-quality
management (e.g. MBA) degree programs also need to be introduced. Initially the focus of these
programs should be to service the manpower needs of the mining sector, but progressively these
programs should become targeted more generically at skills for broad-based economic
development.

137.    Despite the challenges associated with and unstable fiscal setting and incomplete fiscal
regime for mining, Mongolia has also made significant progress in the implementation of the
EITI Mongolia has prepared and disseminated its first reconciliation report for the 2006 fiscal
year and is currently preparing the second report for 2007. Mongolia's next step is to seek
validation of its processes and actions in order for the country to be deemed an "EITI-compliant"
country by the International EITI Board. This requires an independent assessment by March 31,
2010 of Mongolia's EITI-related activities, and certifies that the process includes a truly multi-
stakeholder process that includes civil society in monitoring the transparency of payments
between mining companies and the various levels of government.

    b) Key measures to be supported by the DPC

138.    The government is committed to position Mongolia to benefit from and effectively
manage any upturn in exploration and development interest associated with commodity price
increases in the future. Its highest priority items are to:

    ·   Review and revise the minerals policy and law to clarify the law and its application in
        key areas such as state equity participation and clarify issues related to the operations of
        the mineral licensing cadastre office.

    ·   Adopt Cadastre (Licensing) regulations that are compatible with international best
        practice, that are either passed by Cabinet or endorsed by Parliament, and that clearly
        define due process with respect to the grant, management, transfer, surrender and
        cancellation of mineral licenses.

    ·   Review the underlying policy setting for the fiscal regime for mining and the
        development of an appropriate legislative framework for the application and management
        of mining taxation that addresses the specific technical aspects unique to the sector.


                                                  45

     ·    Develop draft model mining investment agreements to form the basis of future
          negotiations for new large-scale mineral developments. These would clarify mining
          policy, including taxation and state ownership, and incorporate responsible mining
          practices.40

139.      Other actions the government is considering to effectively develop the minerals sector
include the development of:

     ·    regulations for management of mining operations including reporting obligations,
          occupational health and safety and environmental performance;

     ·    mine closure and rehabilitation regulations and guidelines to address biophysical,
          economic and social aspects of mine closure as well as the development of fiscal
          arrangements relating to closure financial surety;41

     ·    legislation and supporting regulation to formalize and regulate the small scale mining
          sector in order to create a legal and regulatory framework for the conversion of ninja
          miners into legitimate, regulated and environmentally sound operations;

     ·    a regulatory framework for the mining, processing and marketing of uranium from
          private sector managed uranium mines in Mongolia. Such regulations should also include
          the development of specific environmental conditions and standards for any discharges of
          water and dust from the sites and the management of occupational standards to maintain
          human health;

     ·    completion of the EITI validation process for Mongolia to become recognized as an
          EITI-compliant country by the International EITI Board by March 31, 2010.

140.      DPC prior actions

     ·    The Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy has developed and adopted model
          investment agreements for the mining sector, clarifying Mongolia's mining policy,
          including taxation and the state's capital participation, and incorporating responsible
          mining practices consistent with the Equator Principles.42
     ·    Sufficient resources have been transferred to the Mongolia EITI Secretariat in order to
          finance an independent validation of its national EITI Program, scheduled to be
          completed by March 31, 2010.

     c) Expected results

141.      The emerging medium-term strategy would build on the above short-term measures as
follows. The overall objective would be to work towards adopting a new mining law and policy,
and ensure, through close monitoring and prudent regulation, that responsible mining practices


40Responsible mining refers to mining activity that does not degrade the environment where mining takes
place, does not exploit miners, and helps enhance social relations.

41In this context, a financial surety is a bond or guarantee that can be exercised if the company defaults on
its legal obligations to restore or rehabilitate the mine site.

42The Equator principles are the set of principles and financial industry benchmarks developed by private
financial institutions for determining assessing and managing social and environmental risks in project
financing. They were established in June 2003 and revised in July 2006, and modeled after the
environmental standards adopted by the World Bank and social policies promoted by the International
Financial Corporation.


                                                        46

are followed in both large and small-scale mining. New mining projects would utilize the draft
model investment agreement. A more efficient and transparent mining cadastre would be in
operation, which would be regulated according to the revised regulatory framework. A new and
relevant division of the Income Tax Law would be adopted to improve industry compliance with
modern taxation practice and to reduce tax disputes. Mongolia will continue to implement and
develop EITI and become recognized as an EITI-compliant country. The number of Mongolians
trained in relevant mining skills would significantly increase.



                            VII.       PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION


     A. Poverty and Social Impact


142.    Recently released poverty numbers are very worrisome and justify the proposed DPC's
explicit focus on protecting the most vulnerable, in addition to managing the downturn. The
latest poverty profile of Mongolia that was published by the government43 shows that even during
the recent years of high economic growth, poverty was not reduced substantially. The poverty
headcount declined little to 35.5 percent in the 2007/08 survey, down from 36.1 percent in the
2002/03 survey, with large regional differences between the Ulaanbaatar and the rural
populations.44 As average incomes rose, this means that inequality has increased significantly.
The Bank is currently working on a series of policy notes using the new data. These notes will
provide further policy analysis to underpin possible future DPCs and work on social protection.
In addition, various consultations have been held in preparation for the proposed operation, in
which these issues have been raised (Section V.B).

143.    Furthermore, the downward revision of growth in 2009 implies that fewer people will be
lifted out of poverty. Economic growth in 2009 has been revised downward from 8 to 2.7 percent.
Based purely on a Bank staff estimate of the historic correlation between economic growth and
